dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: +.+.ON a young man and young woman, both black, both twen both smiling. It would be twilight, the sound of the city winding down around this couple, nothing but their footsteps and the m hum of this quiet street.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: You ready for this?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. (and) Ain’t nothin’ else in the world I'm more ready for. And as they draw closer, locked in a kiss... ...the sound of metal clanging, of feet shuffling and men voices filling a tinny room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same young couple eyeing each other across glass, the young man on the one side in the jail smocks with tired e on the other, a thin pretty girl, a gentle wonder about h This is TISH (19, black, warm), the voice heard "before anything else” and Alonzo “FONNY” Hunt (22, also black, breakable).

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Alonzo... Fonny’s eyes starting at the sound of his proper name, something sharp, a warning in its use: she never calls hi Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Alonzo... we're going to have a baby. Fonny going blank, completely blank as that news washes o him, just across that glass and yet, instantly so far awa from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m glad Fonny, I’m glad. Don’t you worry.

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE FRAME
dialogues.text: .»».on Fonny’s face, still frozen in contemplation, the l of a life changing. “I should have said already: we're not married. That mean more to him than it does to me, but I understand how he feels. Fonny is twenty-two. I'm nineteen.”

dialogues.speaker: RESUMING
dialogues.text: Fonny closing his eyes, just a moment to himself, then:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No. I ain’t sure, I’m just trying to mess with your mind. Fonny smiling now, coming back to her:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: What we goin’ to do?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Well... we ain’t goin’ to drown it. So I guess we’ll have to raise it. Fonny throwing his head back, a big, shocking laughter, a in his face initially unfathomable:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Did you tell Frank?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You tell your folks?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Not yet. But don’t worry about them, I just wanted to tell you first.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess that makes sense. My daddy and ‘nem can’t keep nothin’ to theyselves, better this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (and now) A baby. Something in this repetition carrying Fonny away from her away to that place beyond Tish. His eyes cast down:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: What you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I’m going to do just like I been doing. I’1l work up to just about the last month. And then, Mama and Sis will take care for me, you ain't got to worry. And anyway, we have you out of here before then.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Of course I’m sure. I’m always sure about that. A man coming up behind Fonny, doesn’t even bother to touc him, from his dress, clearly a guard. Fonny’s eyes going down at the man’s presence, looks thro that glass again at his lover. His eyes coming back, that overwhelming smile again. Tish matching it, the two of th standing in unison on either side of the glass. Fonny raises his fist to the glass. Tish does the same. Off Tish watching Fonny move away, disappear through a do on the other side... INT. TISH’S HOME - DAY A simple Harlem apartment, modest but expansive as far as these things go, a proper living room, kitchen big enough fit a small dining table. Along a hall running perpendicular to the living room, th bedrooms. Tish sitting before a steaming cup of tea, staring at the wispy steam rising off it. A beat, then... ...the sound of the front door opening, of footsteps on w flooring and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) How you doin’ Little One? A moment later, SHARON (early 40s but could pass for youn enters, a shopping bag at her side. Just in the way she l at her, Tish’s mother.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: He’s just the same. He’s fine. He sends his love.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Good. You see the lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Not today. I have to go on Monday, after work.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: He been to see Fonny?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No. A sigh from Sharon as she tosses her hat to the couch, be toward the kitchen. Tish following, tracks over to where Sharon places the shopping bag, begins unloading its cont to the cupboard. The two working in silence a moment, Sharon humming as sh alternates the spray of water rinsing vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Mama...?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Yeah, Lil’ Bit? Tish not going further and Sharon not pressing. Sharon turning off the tap, turns and looks at her daught Watches her a long beat. A very slow realization. INT. TISH’S HOME, TISH’S BEDROOM - DAY A simple bed and bed-side table, dresser-drawer at the fo of the bed with an oversized mirror atop it. Heavy curtai in here. It’s day but cool and dark. Sharon puts a hand to Tish’s forehead, gentle. That same on Tish’s shoulder now:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tish, I don’t think you got nothing to cry about. (and now) You tell Fonny?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I just told him today. I figured I should tell him first.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You did right. And I bet he just grinned all over his face.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yes. (wipes a tear) He sure did.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You must be - let’s see - you about three months gone?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: What you cryin’ about? Sharon pulling Tish fully in, the curiosity over, all mothering now.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Now listen, you got enough on your mind without worrying about being a bad girl and all that jive-ass shit. I sure hope I raised you better than that. If you was a bad girl you wouldn't be sitting on this bed, you’d long been turning tricks for the warden. Tish picking her head up, wiping more tears, getting hers back together:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Now you and Fonny be together right now, married or not, wasn't for that damn white man. So, let me tell you what you got to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to hold on to that baby, don't care what else happens or don't happen. You got to do that. Can't nobody else do that for you. And we going to get Fonny out. And that baby be the best thing that ever happened to him. It’s going to give him a whole lot of courage. (beat) Am I getting through to you?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Now, when your Daddy and Ernestine get home, we going to sit at the table together, and I'll make the family announcement. I think that might be easier, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. Sharon rises from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Take off them streets clothes and lie down for a minute. I'll come get you. Sharon opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Mama?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Yes, Tish?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (laughing) I don’t know what you thanking me for. I’m your mama, ain’t I? Sharon closing the door behind her, leaves Tish in here alone. Tish taking off her coat and shoes, slowly, all th tiredness overtaking her again. As she gets her shoes to floor... ..+.the doorbell rings. From somewhere out there, we can Sharon yell, "Be right there!" Before she answers the front door, however, she’s at thi bedroom door again, a quick knock and she’s entering.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Here. Drink this. Do you good. Sharon carrying a small saucer, has a small water glass a shot glass beside. Sharon taking the brown liquid of the glass, pours it into the water. And then she’s gone again, out that door, heels clicking along the hall that leads to the front door. From the sou of the banter, a man entering, in a good mood:

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Forgot my keys, Tish home yet?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's taking a little nap inside.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She see Fonny?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. She saw him. She saw the inside of the Tombs, too. That's why I made her lie down.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about the lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She going to see him Monday. Sound of feet moving throughout the house now, of the fri door opening and closing. Tish downing her water and bran

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How much you think them damn lawyers is going to cost us before this thing over?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Joe, you know damn well ain't no point in asking me that question.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well. They sure got it made, the rotten motherfuckers.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Amen to that.  Tish lying back on the bed, looking up and into those curtains. Somewhere out there, the sun setting. As she rubs her belly, let’s her thoughts wonder... CUT TO BLACK. “Fonny used to go to a vocational school where they teach kids to make all kinds of shitty things..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See a “slightly” younger Fonny working at a table-saw, a piece of timber split down the trunk atop his work statio “,..like card tables and hassocks and chests of drawers w nobody's ever going to buy.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “But Fonny didn't go for it at all and he split, taking m of the wood from the workshop with him." Looking out through the open shop-gate, a worn-out pickup truck illuminated in flash light beams as Fonny wonders t empty shop floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny wiping sweat from his face as the smoker fills the “He started working as a short-order cook in a barbecue j — so he could eat — and he found a basement where he coul work on his wood and he was at our house more than he was his."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple, at best seems a squatter’s refuge, a pallet in th corner of the room, a handmade dining table. “Fonny gave Mama one of his first sculptures." In the center of the space, Fonny working at two saw-hors sanding a suggestive piece. CLOSE ON: The mantle, a small, wooden sculpture there of naked man with one hand at his forehead and the other hal hiding his sex. “The legs are long and wide apart and the whole motion o figure is torment. It seemed a strange figure for him to or, at least, it seemed strange until you thought about i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny here working on those table-saws as before. “You see, Fonny had found something that he wanted to do, this saved him from the death that was waiting to overtak the children of our age. And though it took many forms...

dialogues.speaker: STILL IMAGE SERIES
dialogues.text: .+-period, still photography of the drug fueled, post-Civ Rights era blight that will come to plague America’s inne cities for decades on end. “,..the death itself was very simple and the cause was simple, too: the kids had been told that they weren't wor shit... and everything they saw around them proved it.” CLOSING STILL IMAGE: Gordon Parke’s “Howl.” END MONTAGE 1. INT. TISH’S HOME, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT A woman we've not seen before entering the apartment now, slender, taller, a few years older than Tish but still yo This is Tish’s sister, ERNESTINE.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Where's Tish? Sharon and JOSEPH (a little older than Sharon, a large, y subtle presence) over near the kitchen, Joe nursing a bee looking in on his wife preparing supper. Both their faces opening at the sight of Ernestine.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: She's home. She's lying down. Ernestine setting her purse down, continuing over to...

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: She all right?  10.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: She's tired. She went to see Fonny.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: How's he taking it?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Taking it.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Lord, let me make myself a drink. You want me to cook?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: No. I'll get into the pots ina minute.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: She see Hayward?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: No. She's seeing him on Monday, after work.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: You going with her?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I think I better.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think so, too, I'll call him from work, before you all get there.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You know... Tish says she thinks that lawyer wants more money.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Daddy, we paid him his retainer, that's why ain't none of us got no clothes. And I know we got to pay expenses, but he ain't supposed to get no more money until he brings Fonny to trial.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: He says it's a tough case.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Shit. What's a lawyer for?  11.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: To make money.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You got that right.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Well. Anybody talk to the Hunts lately?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: They don't want to know nothing about it, you know that. Mrs. Hunt and them two camellias is just in disgrace. And poor Frank ain't got no money.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Well. Let's not talk too much about it in front of Tish. We'll work it out somehow.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Shit. We got to work it out. Fonny's like one of us.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: He is one of us. All heads turning here at a bit of light out in the livin room, the sound of footsteps approaching. A moment later Tish appears, hair mottled and cajoled, just woke up:

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Well hello there, baby sister. A kiss on the cheek and a hug between Tish and Ernestine: these too clearly love each other.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You want a 1il’ snack, Tish?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No thank you, I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Well alright then, if y’all want to eat, better get your behinds out of my kitchen, this food ain’t gon’ fix itself. Come on now, take your business into the living room.  12. Tish and Ernestine shuffling away from here, leaving thei mother to her kitchen. Sharon looking to Joe there, the m shrugging a “what’d I do” face:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Do I come down to your job and watch you work? Joe smiling as Sharon turns away from him, all sly eyes a persuasive hips as we CUT TO...

dialogues.speaker: A RECORD NEEDLE
dialogues.text: ...lowered deftly to the third cut on a pristine LP. INT. TISH’S HOME - NIGHT - LATER Ernestine lowering that needle, a freshly lit cigarette i her left hand as something soulful and heavy overcomes th room (Nina Simone, etc.). The lights dimmed now, vibe changed as Ernestine looks ba at the family gathered at the dining table, Joe, Sharon a Tish, the remnants of dinner laid out before them. Ernestine closing her eyes, swaying to the rhythm as thou somewhere else altogether:

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Sing to me Nina, sing. Sharon rising from the dining table as Ernestine approach gets to collecting dishes as Ernestine sits back to the table. Joe drifting into the kitchen as well, the music pacing everything. Sharon reaches up to an obscure cupboard, just above the stove, kind of cupboard that’s rarely opened. Fetches a dusty, ornate bottle from there.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: What you doin’ with that?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: What you think? Get the good glasses. Sharon moving back over to the dining table with Tish and Ernestine, sets that bottle of French Brandy to the table Ernestine’s eyes going from Sharon's to Tish. Ernestine’s eyes... smiling. Ernestine’s eyes never leaving Tish.  13.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (at Joe) You the man of the house, start pouring.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (faux accent) But of course, Madame. Joe setting a nice enough snifter before each of them, go around the table in turns and pours a little brandy into each. As he bends to pour Tish’s...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Just a lil’ bit for Tish, now.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Alright, what’s the deal? Sharon looking to Joe, then at Ernestine, then at Tish. S smiles at Tish:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: This... is a sacrament. And no, I ain’t gone crazy. We’re drinking to a new life. (beat) Tish is gonna have Fonny’s baby. The air heavy in here for a beat, no one moving. Sharon reaches a hand to Joe’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (softly) Drink. Joe staring at Tish, frozen in the moment of that news. Tish staring back, holding his gaze, only openness. Joe puts his glass down. Then he picks it up again. He’s trying to speak but he can't. A moment more of this awkwardness, then... .+-a smile more sweet than bitter developing in Joe’s fac

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: That's a hell of a note. Joe takes a sip of his brandy, a good, deep swallow:

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Ain't you going to drink to the little one, Tish?  14. Tish nodding, takes the lightest sip of that brandy, stil rouses a cough in her, Ernestine patting her on the back.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: How long this been going on?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: About three months.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's what I figured.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Three months! ?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Since March.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: While you two was running around looking at places? Joe asking this question as much to himself as to anyone else. The women understanding, allowing that question the proper space to drift out, refract. After a moment, after a few more long sips:

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You sure you want this baby?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, and Fonny wants it, too. It's our baby, don't you see? And it's not his fault that he’s in jail, it’s not like he ran away. (pleading) And we've always been best friends, ever since we were little, you know that. And we'd be married now, if-if--

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Your father know that. He's only worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Don't you go thinking I think you a bad girl, or any foolishness like that. I just asked you that because you so young, that's all, and--  15.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (raising her glass) Un-bow your head sister.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: To the newborn.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I hope it’s a boy, that’d tickle old Frank to pieces, I bet. (a thought grabbing him) Tish, do you mind... if I break the news to him?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No daddy, I don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (with attitude) I sure would like to be the one to tell them sisters.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Joe, why don't you just call up and ask them all over here? Hell, it's Saturday night and it ain't late and we still got a lot of brandy in the bottle. And now that I think about it, it's really the best way to do it. Joe looking to his wife, had already started for his coat but... considering Sharon’s proposal:

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You know you right love, let’s get them over here. Joe turning down that long hall adjoining the bedrooms. A his footfalls pad away, we stay here, with these women listening to Joe on the phone down that hall. Beat. Joe coming back down that hallway now, re-enters the livi room, takes a seat at the one recliner in here:

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hunt... is getting dressed. (smiles at Tish) Come on over here, daughter. Tish rising from her spot on the couch, moves from mother father, sits beside Joe, head rested to his shoulder:  16.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You're a good girl, Tish. I’m proud of you. Don’t you forget that.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: She ain't going to forget it. I’1ll whip her ass if she do.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: But she’s pregnant! A big, way deep down laugh from all of them at this, Ernestine and Sharon both throwing their heads back. As the laughter subsides...

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Shall we dress for Mrs. Hunt? Another laugh now, something in the room spreading.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Look. We got to be nice, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Oh we'll be nice; Lord knows we'll be nice, you raised us right. It’s just you didn’t never buy us no clothes. But Mrs. Hunt and them sisters, they got wardrobes! Ain't no sense in trying to compete with them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I didn’t run no tailor shop.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Well who’s fault is that? Ernestine rubbing her father’s head playfully as she move from the living room, Joe smiling at her touch. Head resting at Joe’s shoulder, eyes lingering across thi room, Tish appears to be somewhere else, lost in the drif “The very first time Fonny and I made love was strange.” EXT. TISH’S HOME - DAY - MONTAGE 2 Sharon at the top of the stairs at Tish’s stoop, Fonny at bottom of the steps, Tish between the two. “It was the day he gave Mama that sculpture.”  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish and Fonny moving down the sidewalk, hand in hand. “I dumped water over Fonny's head and scrubbed Fonny's ba in the bathtub, in a time that seems so long ago."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETAILS of him making his way along this walk, as strong we've seen him, dressed in a red and black lumberjack coa grey corduroy slacks and heavy shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those same DETAILS of her. “I don't remember that we ever had any curiosity concerni each other's bodies. Fonny loved me too much.” Fonny taking Tish’s hand in his. “And that meant that there had never been any occasion fo shame between us.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a beat this moment, this downtown train packed as th are bound to be. The couple standing, wedged into the corner of this train oblivious to everything around them, Tish fully leaned in Fonny’s embrace. Just the shimmy of the train, that rocking side to side. Tish’s eyes distinctly, noticeably staring at Fonny’s lip looking up into them. As he parts his lips to speak...

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE FRAME
dialogues.text: “He was the most beautiful person I had seen in all my li RESUMING: Fonny continuing whatever it is he’s saying her can’t make it out above the howl of the tracks and chatte the crowd. Off Fonny repeating himself... and Tish not responding, s lost in those lips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light falling, getting on to dusk.  18. Fonny and Tish moving, slowly tracing the paths of this p passing the wayfarers so integral to the charm of this pl Somehow, the two not touching here: Tish’s arms folded ab herself, Fonny’s hands clasped behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I've slept in this park sometimes. (off her look) No, it’s not a good idea. Fonny reaching into his coat pocket now, retrieving a cigarette. Gestures to Tish:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Not right now, thank you. (and innocently) Why did you sleep in the park? Fonny taking a quick beat to get his cigarette lit:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: It was late. Didn’t want to go home. Didn't want to wake up none of you neither. Check’s Tish’s response: clearly she’s never assumed some she loves has had to sleep in this park.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: But I got me a pad down here now. I'll show it to you, you want to see it?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (after a nod) I'd like that. These two still walking, circling a path around the park. Fonny reaches an arm out, pulls her in close:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Good. (and) You want to eat down here or you want to wait till we get back uptown?  19.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or you want to go to the movies or you want a little wine or you want a little pot or a beer or a cup of coffee? (and, a smile) Or you just want to walk a little more before you make up your mind? Fonny’s grinning now, warm and sweet, brings his arm back from around her and takes her hand in his, swinging it li little boy; a happy little boy. END MONTAGE. INT. TISH’S HOME, FRONT DOOR - NIGHT The doorbell ringing, resounding throughout the apartment Seems no one’s here at first, then... ..-Ernestine appearing, dressed the same as before, didn’ bother to change. Gets to that door and...

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hunt, how do you do, only way to get to see you people is to call an emergency summit, now you know that ain’t right? A hollow kiss on the cheek from MRS. HUNT (50 but attempt to look younger... and it shows). As she passes, reveals young women, similar to Tish and Ernestine in age. The girls moving past Ernestine with a look, something mi school about it all. Coming up behind them is FRANK (50s, handsome but tired). He and Ernestine share a genuine hug move together into...

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: ..-enter the space and find an odd bit of domestic spacin Sharon with a hand on her hip, watching from near the kitchen. Joe standing with Tish in his embrace at his sid Mrs. Hunt and her girls stand on the opposite side of the room, a semi-circle with their hands doing various awkwar things. The Hunt women are all over-dressed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: So you saw my big-headed boy today?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. He’s fine. He sends his love.  20.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: They ain’t giving him too hard a time, is they? I ask you like that because, you know, he might say things to you he won’t say to me.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S8.)
dialogues.text: Lovers’ secrets. Tish’s eyes cutting to the source of that voice: ADRIENNE the older of the two Hunt sisters (with SHEILA being the other), sitting on the couch now, crossing her legs and folding those arms with a shit-eating smirk.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Well. He hates it, you can see that. And he should. But he’s strong. He’ll be alright... but we've got to get him out of there.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: If he’d done his reading and his studying when he should have, he wouldn’t be in there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK JOSEPH
dialogues.text: What you know about it you-- You bring that six-pack man?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Or I got some gin and we got whiskey and we got some brandy. Ain’t got no Thunderbird though-- (and, to Mrs. Hunt) I’m sure you ladies won’t mind?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: Mind? Frank does not care if we mind.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hunt, what can I get you, sugar? I can offer you some tea, or coffee; and we got ice cream, and Coca Cola.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Yeah Mrs. Hunt, I can make you an ice-cream soda. Come on Sheila, you want to help me? (grabbing Sheila) Sit down Mama, me and Sheila got it.  21. Sharon taking Sheila’s place now, Mrs. Hunt having sat be her daughters on the couch there:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Lord, the time sure flies. We ain’t hardly seen each other since this trouble started.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: Don't say a word. I have been running myself sick, all up and down the Bronx, trying to get the very best legal advice I can find. I just pray and pray and pray that the Lord will bring my boy to the light. That's all I pray for, every day and every night. A long pause from Mrs. Hunt here, moment of reflection:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: And then, sometimes I think that maybe this is the Lord's way of making my boy think on his sins and surrender his soul to Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You might be right. The Lord sure works in mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Now he may try you. But he ain’t never left none of His children alone.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: What you think of the lawyer Ernestine found, Mr. Hayward?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: I haven't seen him yet. (defensive) I just have not had time to get downtown. But I know Frank saw him--

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: What you think Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) It’s a white boy who’s been to law school and he got them degrees. I ain’t got to tell you what that means: it don’t mean shit.  22.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: You're talking to a woman.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm hip, and it’s a mighty welcome change. (pause) Like I was saying, it don’t mean shit and I ain’t sure we’re going to stay with him. On the other hand, as white boys go, he’s not so bad: he’s young and hungry, so he’s not as full of shit now as he may be when he’s full.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: But I keep trying to tell you, that it's that negative attitude, you're so full of hate! If you give people hatred, they will give it back to you! Every time I hear you talk this way my heart breaks for my son, sitting in a dungeon which only the love of God can bring him out of.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: He's not talking hatred, Maybeline. He's just telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: I trust in God, I know He cares for me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know how God expects a man to act when his son is in a cage. Your God crucified His son and was probably glad to get rid of him, but I ain't like that. I ain't hardly going out in the street and kiss the first white cop I see. But I'll be a very loving motherfucker the day my son walks out of that hellhole, free. Oh, I'll be full of love, that day. Mrs. Hunt puts her head in her hands as Frank slowly cros the room again, sits near Joe at the dining table.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: Mr. Rivers, exactly what is the purpose of this meeting?  23.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven't called us all the way over here just to watch my father insult my mother?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Why not? It's Saturday night. You can't tell what people won't do if they get bored enough. Maybe we just invited you over to liven things up?

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: I can believe that you're that malicious... but I can't believe you're that stupid. Off Tish, CUT TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a table more to the side than the back — none of that — find Fonny and Tish, a continuation of their date begun the previous “Montage 2.”

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (calling out) Pedrocito, que pasa? ¢éPodemos tener algtin servicio, por favor? Tish looking on wide-eyed, has never seen him speak Spani A server (PEDROCITO, 20s) approaching, a smile on his fac

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: (mocking) “Servicio, servicio.” (and at Tish) Senorita, how may I help you, I’m sorry your company tonight is less than desirable but this can’t be helped.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: No se puede evitar, mi culo. Laughter from the two of them:

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: Oye, estas con una mujer, encantadora! Tish in heaven here, eyes fixed on Fonny, roving from him Predocito and back.  24. As the men continue their banter, jostling and joking lik old friends, their voices drift off the soundtrack: “I had never seen Fonny outside the world in which I move had seen him with his father and his mother, and I had se him with us."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...face spread wide in a smile, looking from Predocito to Tish and back, from Pedrocito to us — right at us — his e alight with some mixture of joy and pride. “I had certainly never seen him in the world in which he moved."

dialogues.speaker: TISH AND FONNY
dialogues.text: ...leaving the restaurant, the meal finished, Pedrocito a few other Spanish men gathered near the exit to see them As Tish looks on... “Perhaps it was only now I was able to see him with me, f he was turned away from me, laughing... but he was holdin hand." As Fonny leads Tish out onto the sidewalk...

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: (calling out) A very good night Sefiorita! You are always welcome here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The holding of hands, a knowing smile playing about Fonny face as he watches Tish. Anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Tish....

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Come and see my place, won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: But... it’s late.  25.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: It ain’t far. Tish looking at him as they continue walking, studying hi face for a clue, then:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Okay, Fonny. (and again) Okay. INT. TISH’S HOME, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT - RESUMING Ernestine and Sheila returning from the kitchen carrying platters of drinks; the smile on Ernestine’s face is pure delight, the one on Sheila’s? Not so much. Ernestine setting down her tray, raising her glass:

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Happy landings. Everyone going quiet now. Everyone... waiting and, in the space of this waiting, everyone's eyes slowly, definitive drawing themselves to...

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: All eyes on Tish, for once alone in the room, neither her parents nor Ernestine beside her. Tish rises, nervous hand running down her waist to smooth dress. She takes a step, just a small one, symbolic, towa Frank:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I called this meeting. I had Daddy ask you all to come over so I could tell you what I had to tell Fonny this afternoon. Mrs. Hunt setting down her ice-cream float. Sharon taking sip of her gin and tonic. Ernestine... smiling.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (deep breath) What I had to tell Fonny this afternoon is... that Fonny’s going to be a father. (and) We're going to have a baby. All at once in this room, several things: Mrs. Hunt’s eye leaving Tish, lowering, eyes to the floor;  26. Frank and Joe turning to one another, holding each other' gaze in silence; Sheila and Adrienne rolling their eyes i contempt; Sharon and Ernestine making eye contact, a wink sip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Joe) You and me? We going to go out and get drunk. A huge laugh of joy from Frank, the clasping of hands bet these two.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (at Tish) I’m glad. Don’t you worry, I’m mighty--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: And who is going to be responsible for this baby?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: The father and the mother. Mrs. Hunt staring, something smoldering in her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You can bet that it won’t be the Holy damn Ghost. Mrs. Hunt shooting Frank a look of disgust, then rising, begins slowly crossing the room:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: I guess you call your lustful action love. I don’t. I always knew you'd be the destruction of my son. The Bible says: “Put to death therefore what is earthly in you: sexual immorality, impurity, passion, evil desire and covetousness.” (and) That child is borne of sin, the Holy Ghost will cause it to shrivel in your womb. But my son will be forgiven. My prayers will--

dialogues.speaker: WOMP
dialogues.text: From nowhere and everywhere, Frank here standing over Mrs Hunt having knocked her senseless, sprawled to the floor.  27.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: Her heart!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I think you’ll find it’s still pumping. But I wouldn’t call it no heart. Frank does not look remorseful, more sad than anything, s over everything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Joe, let the women take care of her and come on with me. Joe hesitating, still shocked by the violence:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Please man, come on.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Go on with him, Joe. Go on. Ernestine moving past Sharon, has a bottle of rubbing alc and a hand full of cotton balls.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Go on. We don’t need you here. Joe nodding at his wife in ascent, eyes on Mrs. Hunt as h rounds the living room, takes his coat from a chair-back, hand to Frank’s shoulder just ahead of him. The women all watching as the men exit, the door slowly closed behind them. Coming back to the living room, an undeniably potent imag these six women alone now in this house, having bared wit to the past moment’s events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hunt getting to her feet slowly, free hand bracing herself as she lowers to the couch.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: That was a terrible thing you said to me. It was the most terrible thing I’ve heard in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: My father didn’t have to slap her.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: She’s got a weak heart.  28.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: She’s got a weak head, the Holy Ghost done softened y’all brain, child: did she forget it was Frank's grandchild she was cursing? I know some men would have cut that weak heart out of your body and gladly gone to hell to pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I don’t think you have the right to sneer at my mother’s faith.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Oh don’t give me that bullshit, you so shamed you got a Holy Roller for a mother, you don’t know what to do. You make me sick.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: You make me sick. Maybe my mother didn't say it exactly like she should have, but he didn’t have to--

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: My father doesn’t hit my mother.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Baby your mother a lot smarter than hers.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: And who do you funky niggers think you are? She only asked one question: ‘Who’s going to raise this baby?’ And who is? Tish ain’t got no education and God knows she ain’t got nothin’ else. And Fonny ain’t never been worth a damn, so who is going to take care of this baby?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I am, you dried up yellow cunt, and you keep on talking, I’m going to take mighty good care of you. Adrienne putting her hands on her hips in response, in Ha an unmistakable challenge. Ernestine pounces:

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Adrienne? Baby? May I tell you something, Sweetie-pie?  29. Ernestine puts one hand very lightly against Adrienne's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Oh, sugar. From the very first day I laid eyes on your fine person, I got hung up on your Adam's apple. I been dreaming about it; it's delicious. I just can't tell, Sweetie, if I want to tear it out with my fingers... or my teeth. It is a thing of beauty. And if you touch my sister, I'm going to have to make up my mind pretty quick, SO... Ernestine moves away from Adrienne, gestures at Tish.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: ...touch her. Go on, please.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I knew we shouldn't have come. I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: My. I must have a dirty mind, Sheila. I didn’t know that you could even say that word.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Ernestine.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE
dialogues.text: Come on Sheila, let’s go. Adrienne moving and Sheila following, the two of them hel Mrs. Hunt to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: I sure hope... (dramatic sigh) ...that you’re pleased with the way you raised your daughters. Sharon just staring at Mrs. Hunt here, says nothing, the whole thing a wonderful spectacle now:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: My girls won't be bringing me no bastards to feed, I can guarantee you that.  30.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: That’s because won’t nobody fuck ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Ernestine! Sharon cocking her head now, finally perplexed by all thi Stares at Mrs. Hunt a long moment:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: But the child that’s coming... is your grandchild. I don’t understand you, it’s your grandchild. What difference does it make how it gets here? The child ain’t got nothing to do with that; don’t none of us have nothing to do with that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: That child.... Looks from Sharon to Tish, starts for the door:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNT
dialogues.text: (moving) That child.... Tish and family watching as the Hunts make their way out silently, everything different now. As we watch them go.. “It's astounding the first time you realize a stranger ha body."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny and Tish standing in this basement apartment. From their dress, a continuation of their dinner at the Spanis restaurant. “The realization that he has a body makes him a stranger. We take the place in as Tish does: a small, low room, but a fireplace. Just off the room is a tiny kitchenette and bathroom. There’s a wooden stool and a couple of hassocks a large wooden table and a smaller one. On the small table, a few empty beer cans and on the larg one, tools. The room smells of wood; there’s raw wood everywhere. In the far corner, a mattress on the floor covered with a Mexican shawl. Fonny's pencil sketches are pinned on the wall. The only other item: a photograph of Frank.  31. “We were to spend a lifetime in this room." Fonny standing across the room from Tish. She’s watching they both know she’s watching him. Fonny crossing to the palette there, takes up that Mexica shawl, walks over to Tish, drapes it over her head and shoulders. Grins and steps back:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I be damned, there’s a rose in Spanish Harlem. Tish smiling, blushing, girlish, how could she not?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Next week, I’m going to get you a rose for your hair. Just a foot of space between them, eyeing each other as t no doubt have many times before. Something different abou this time, though. Fonny spells it out:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: We're grown up now, you know? Tish nods, can’t speak right now, too much going through mind to get there.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: And you've always been mine, no? Again that nod.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: And you know... that I’ve always been yours, right? Tish thinking, so much thinking right now:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I never thought about it that way.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Think about it now.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I just.... Tish’s lips quivering now, whatever emotion this is it’s coming upon her fast and heavy, pushing and pulling:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I just know that I love you.  32. She's crying now, Fonny closing the space between them, removing that shawl and pulling her into him.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I love you too... but I try not to cry about it. Fonny laughing, a sweet laugh, a smile and then another k harder this time, the passion of it removing that lightne

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (serious) I want you to marry me. (at her shock) That's right. I’m yours and you’re mine and that’s it. Fonny holding Tish away from him now, a bit of space to t her in, to read her. She’s processing.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Now, I’ve got to try to explain something to you. Fonny leads Tish (gently) over to his worktable:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: This is where my life is, my real life. Fonny picks up a small piece of wood. There’s the hope of eye gouged into it, the suggestion of a nose.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: This might turn out all right one day, it might not. I don't know a thing about it yet. He puts it down again, very gently, looks at Tish with hi little smile.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Now, listen, I ain't the kind of joker going to give you a hard time running around after other chicks and shit like that. I smoke a little pot but I ain't never popped no needles and I'm really just a square, but.... Fonny taking a moment to gather his thoughts, looks at he very quietly, very hard.  33.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: But... I live with wood and stone. I got stone in the basement and I'm working up here all the time and I'm looking for a loft where I can really work. So, all I'm trying to tell you is... I ain't offering you much. I ain't got no money and I work at odd jobs, just for bread, because I ain't about to go for none of their jive-ass okeydoke. And that means that you going to have to work, too, and when you come home most likely I'll just grunt and keep on with my chisels and shit and maybe sometimes you'll think I don't even know you're there. But don't ever think that, ever. You're with me all the time, without you I don't know if I could make it at all, and when I put down the chisel, I'll always come to you. I'll always come to you, ‘cause I need you, understand? Is that all right, Tish?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course it’s alright with me. I love you. Fonny not smiling, instead just watching her, the opennes their eyes here. He pulls her in close, kisses her, with feeling than before. Tish gives herself over to him. Fonny taking her hand, leading her away from the center o the room, over to that palette. Turns his back to it, sit the edge before pulling Tish down to him, a bit awkward a first but settling in, her body at his feet, head at his Fonny caresses her cheek, leans down over and kisses her, heat between them mounting. His hands finding their way, undoing Tish’s blouse, expos her, the shock of everything at first a start on Tish’s f then an agreement, a joining. Fonny pulling Tish onto the bed, undressing her, carefull gently, kissing her the whole way. She's naked. Fonny rising, scans the room and retrieves that shawl. Mo back to the bed, takes a warm look at Tish there, covers with the shawl. Disappears away from the room.  34. Beat; a beat here with Tish as she listens to Fonny in th bathroom , the sound of him pissing, the toilet flushing, quickly running water. A brief moment of quiet then... Fonny reappearing, fully naked, Tish watching him as he crosses the room, the full him as he moves through the space, approaches the one lam this room and...

dialogues.speaker: DARKNESS
dialogues.text: .--but not BLACK, the street light through the windows th a generous angle in this basement apartment, a muted qual to the light, just enough to make them out. Fonny slipping beneath the shawl with Tish, his body atop hers but bearing his own weight. Looks down to her:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Now don’t be scared. (and) Don’t be scared. Just remember that I belong to you. Just remember that I wouldn't hurt you for nothing in this world. You just going to have to get used to me. And we got all the time in the world Tish meeting his eyes, nodding without moving. Fonny look down at her now, down her body as he maneuvers beneath th shawl:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Don’t be scared. Hold onto me. Off a clinched, guttural exhale from Tish’s lips, her thr her gut...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaths, all breaths and pants and sighs from somewhere d a thirst for air to keep from drowning in release. Fonny holding himself just above Tish, both shaking, both sweating, from the shape of Tish’s back, everything tense pushed to its limit. That shawl gone now, wadded in a ball in some impossible location away from them. Fonny looking down at the space between their naked bodies. He can be such a little boy, guilty smile:  35.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (sotto) I’m sorry to have made such a mess. But I guess you don’t want to have no baby right away and I didn’t have no protection.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (whispered) I think I made a mess too. Isn’t there supposed to be blood? (a flash of shyness) It was my first time. Did you know? From Fonny’s endearing look: of course he did.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (sotto) I had a hemorrhage. Shall we look?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (whispered) I don’t mind. (and) Why are we whispering? That smile again:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (sotto) It’s what people do when they screw. Even Tish not naive enough to go for that, smacks him playfully, Fonny laughing it away:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I like lying here like this.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I do too. Do you like me? (and) I mean - when I make love to you - do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: You just want to hear me say it.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: That's true. (and) So....  36.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: So why don't you go ahead and say it? Fonny kisses her. Clearly he’s a man in love.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Well... it was a little bit like being hit by a truck... (and) -..-but it was the most beautiful thing that ever happened to me. A long, silent beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. (and) For me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite the lack of a crowd, Fonny and Tish standing at t center of this car, wedged against one another, Fonny holding, protecting Tish. EXT. TISH’S HOME - DAY (DAWN) Fonny and Tish arriving on her stoop, hand in hand, the s rising over Harlem. We see these quick beats as Tish describes them: “TI thought Fonny would leave me there, but he took me by hand and said...." Fonny, directly at us, all mouth and lips:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: TISH’S FRONT DOOR OPENING ..-Ernestine revealed there, an initial look of recogniti followed by... a knowing smile.  37. INT. TISH’S HOME - DAY Still in this threshold, Ernestine just within, Tish and Fonny just beyond.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: You're just in time for coffee.

dialogues.speaker: TISH FONNY
dialogues.text: We was-— Good morning, Miss Rivers, I’m sorry we comin’ in so late. Can I speak to Mr. Rivers, please? It’s important. These two standing side by side, hand in hand, a unit. Th smile in Ernestine’s eyes again:

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: It might be easier to see him if you come inside out that hall.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Sis, we--

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: --want to get married. Both Ernestine and Tish looking at Fonny with wild eyes, heart racing, that blurted out, forced its way out of him

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Then you better have some coffee, come on in here. Ernestine turning, leading the two of them into the apartment. From somewhere inside:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now where have you two been ‘till this hour of the morning?

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: ..-Ernestine at the dining table nursing a cup of coffee, Sharon at the pot preparing another, by the looks of thin preparing quite a few. As Fonny and Tish edge closer:  38.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Don’t you know better than to be behaving like that? I declare, we was just about to call the police. Sharon looking across the kitchen at Ernestine, the two exchanging a look that makes this clear: they are not ups having a good time with this. That lost on Fonny though, he’s nervous as hell:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Mrs. Rivers, it’s all my fault. Tish inching closer to Fonny, right on his hip...

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I hadn’t seen Tish for a few weeks and we had a lot to talk about; I had a lot to talk about, I kept her out.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Talking? ...Tish inching away from Fonny.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (nervous ) We.... The room dead quiet. In Sharon’s eyes, expectation:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: We... want to get married. (all downhill now) That’s how come I kept her out so late. I love Tish. That’s why I stayed away so long. I even.... (looks to Tish, a pain) ...I even went to see other girls and, I did all kinds of things, to kind of get it out of my mind. (checks Tish: still down) But I could see I was just fooling myself. I didn’t love nobody else but her. And then I got scared that maybe she’d go away or somebody else would come along and take her away and so I came back. (squeezes her hand) I came runnin’ back. And I don’t have to go away again.  39.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's always been my girl, you know that. And... I’m not a bad boy. You know that. And you’re... you’re the only family I’ve ever had. A long, pronounced silence.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Now see, that's why I can’t figure out why you callin’ me Mrs. Rivers all of a sudden. (and at Tish) I hope you realize, Miss, that you ain't but eighteen years old.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: That argument and a subway token will get you from here to the corner.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (at Ernestine) What do you think about all this?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Me? I’m delighted to be rid of the little brat. I never could see what all the rest of you saw in her, I swear. Take some sugar Fonny, you're going to need it if you intend to tie yourself up with my sweet little sister.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (calling out) Joe! Come on out here, lightning’s done struck the poorhouse! Come on now, I mean it! Fonny taking Tish’s hand, as much to protect himself as t comfort her. Sound of Joe approaching, Tish and Fonny ope their stance to face him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (measured) I'd like you to tell me exactly what you mean young lady by walking in here this hour of the morning. If you want to leave home, then you leave home, you hear? But as long as you in my house, you got to respect it. You hear me?  40. Joe's gaze shifting to Fonny. Fonny immediately releasing Tish’s hand, takes a deep breath:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Mr. Rivers, please don't scold her. It's all my fault, sir. I kept her out. I had to talk to her. I asked her to marry me. That's what we were doing out so long. We want to get married. That's why I'm here. You're her father. You love her. And so I know you know - you have to know - that I love her. I've loved her all my life. You know that. And if I didn't love her, I wouldn't be standing in this room now - would I? I could have left her on the stoop and run away again. I know you might want to beat me up. But I love her. That's all I can tell you. Joe looking at the boy, that same poker face as Sharon:

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I’m twenty-one, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You think that’s old enough to get married?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I don’t know sir, but it’s old enough to know who you love.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I know so.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: How you going to feed her?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: How did you? Joe's jaw tightening. Ernestine pushes a cup of coffee in direction.  41.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You got a job?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I load moving vans in the daytime and I sculpt at night. I'ma sculptor. We know it won't be easy. They stare at each other again. Joseph picking up his cof without looking at it, sips it without tasting it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Now, let me get this straight. You asked my little girl to marry you, and she said--

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: And you come here to tell me or to ask my permission?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Both, sir. Both men measuring each other. Joe puts his coffee down.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: What would you do in my place?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I'd ask my daughter. If she tells you she don't love me, I'll go away and I won't never bother you no more. Joe looks hard at Fonny, a long look, as though he wants knock Fonny down, as though he wants to take him in his a

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (at Tish) You love him, Tish?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. (and) Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes. Joe looking from Fonny to Tish, the two of them joining hands, Tish to the side of but just behind Fonny, likely first time Joe has ever seen a man between him and his daughter.  42. A weighted, but lovely silence around the room. All of th slipping into the inevitability of this moment as we... CUT TO BLACK. And OVER BLACK, super-impose a period specific case-file, frame within the frame against BLACK: yellowed paper with brown horizontal lining, a hand written police report. We this text as Tish narrates: “Mrs. Victoria Rogers, née Victoria Maria San Felipe Sanc declares that on the evening of March 5, between the hour eleven and twelve, in the vestibule of her home, she was criminally assaulted by a man she now knows to have been Alonzo ‘Fonny' Hunt, and was used by the aforesaid Hunt i the most extreme and abominable sexual manner, and forced undergo the most unimaginable sexual perversions."

dialogues.speaker: A STILL PHOTO
dialogues.text: .-+.Still this frame within the frame against BLACK, a ph of Victoria Rogers, not crime related. Dressed simply, looking right at us. A portrait. We’ll cy through a series of these portraits as Tish continues: “I have never seen her. I know only that an American-born Irishman went to Puerto Rico six years ago and there, met Victoria, who was then eighteen. He married her and broug her to New York." IMAGE 2: Victoria and her Irishman, standing in front of New York courthouse. “Having pumped three children out of her, he left.” IMAGE 3: A simple establishing image of Orchard Street. “Her ‘home’ is on Orchard Street; Orchard Street, if you New York, is a very long way from Bank Street." IMAGE 4: An establishing image of Bank Street. “Orchard Street is damn near in the East River and Bank Street is practically in the Hudson." IMAGE 5/SERIES: Alternating stills of Orchard and Bank streets to illustrate their distance from one another. “It is not possible to run from Orchard to Bank Street, particularly not with the police behind you. Yet, Officer Bell swears he saw Fonny ‘run' from the scene of the crim  43. IMAGE 6: Rather than Victoria, a face we’ve not seen befo a red-headed, blue-eyed officer staring right at us. “This is possible only if Officer Bell were off duty, for "beat" is on the West Side, not the East." IMAGE 7: Fonny in cuffs, being forced into a squad car by aforementioned Bell. “And yet it is now up to the accused to prove — and pay f proving — the irregularity and improbability of this sequ of events.” END SEQUENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish and Sharon sitting beside one another in a very typi very oak strewn law office. Across from them, a man who’s name we’ve heard but not me HAYWARD (late 30s, white), Fonny’s lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Well, as you ladies know, this is a very difficult case.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: That's why my sister hired you.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: And you are beginning to feel now that her confidence was misplaced? Hayward smiling through that: he gets it. Lights a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No. I wouldn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: We miss him, that’s all. This is... it’s getting to us.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: I can certainly understand that, and I'm doing all I can to get him back to you just as fast as I can. But, as you ladies know, the very greatest difficulty has been caused by the refusal of Mrs. Rogers to reconsider her testimony. And now she has disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Disappeared? But...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: How can she just disappear?

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: This is a very big city, a very big country, for that matter, a very big world. People disappear. I don't think that she has gone very far, they certainly do not have the means for a long journey. But her family may have returned her to Puerto Rico. In any case, in order to find her, I will need special investigators, and--

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: That means money.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Unfortunately....

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (sotto) That filthy bitch. (and again) That filthy bitch. Sharon reaching a hand to Tish’s back:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: How much money?

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: I’m trying to keep it as low as possible, but special investigators are... special, I'm afraid, and they know it.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Puerto Rico.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: We don't know that she’s returned there, but it is a very vivid possibility. Anyway, she and her new man disappeared some days ago from the apartment on Orchard St..  45.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: But doesn't it make it look bad for her story, to just disappear like that? She's the key witness in this case.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Yes. But she is a ‘distraught, ignorant, Puerto Rican woman, suffering from the aftereffects of rape. So her behavior is not incomprehensible.’ (beat) You see what I mean? Hayward watching Tish, makes sure she gets what he’s sayi

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: And she is only one of the key witnesses in this case. You have forgotten the testimony of Officer Bell; his was the really authoritative identification of the rapist. It is Bell who swears that he saw Alonzo running away from the scene of the crime. And I have always been of the opinion — you will remember that we discussed this — that it is his testimony which Mrs. Rogers continually repeats-——

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: If he saw Fonny at the scene of the crime, then why did he have to wait and come and get him out of the house?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tish. (and to Hayward) You mean — let me get you straight now — that it's that Officer Bell who tells her what to say?

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: You're saying--

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: That there's no way of getting at the truth in this case?  46. Off both their nonplussed faces:

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: If I didn't believe in Alonzo's innocence, I would never have taken the case. Now, the two of you insist that you were together, in the room on Bank Street, along with an old friend, Daniel Carty. Your testimony, as you can imagine, counts for nothing, and Daniel Carty has just been arrested by the DA's office and is being held incommunicado. I have not been allowed to see him. Hayward rises and paces to the window.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: What they are doing is really against the law, but... Daniel has a record. They obviously intend to make him change his testimony. And, I do not know this, but I am willing to bet that that is how and why Mrs. Rogers has disappeared. So. You see. I will make it as easy as I can. But it will still be very hard.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: How soon do you need the money?

dialogues.speaker: HAYWARD
dialogues.text: I’ve begun the operation already of tracing the lady. I’1l need the money aS soon as you can get it. I’ll also force the DA's office to allow me to see Daniel Carty, but they will throw every conceivable obstacle in my way--

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: So we're trying... to buy time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny and Tish across that familiar divide.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: The fuck we going to do about Mrs. Rogers? Where the fuck did she go?  47.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (calming) I don't know. But we'll find her.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: How you going to find her?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: We're sending people to Puerto Rico. We think that's where she went.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: And suppose she went to Argentina? Or Chile? Or China?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: How's she going to get that far?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: They can give her the money to go anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: The DA's office, that's who!

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Fonny--

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You don't believe me? You don't think they can do it?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I don't think they have.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: How you going to get the money to find her?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: We're all working, all of us.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. My Daddy's working in the garment center, you're working in a department store, your Daddy's working on the waterfront--

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Fonny, listen--  48.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Listen to what? What we going to do about that fucking lawyer? He don't give a shit about me, he don't give a shit about nobody! You want me to die in here? You know what's going on in here? You know what's happening to me? To me in here? Fonny’s head going down to that desk, has to hide the moisture we clearly see falling to the table-top before h wiped as quick as it falls, gotta stay a man.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. I don't mean none of that for you. I'm sorry. I love you. You know that, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I do. And I understand what you goin’ through, I’m with you baby. Fonny nodding that in, convincing himself. That smile aga

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: How's the baby coming?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: It's growing. I'll start showing more next month. Eye each other across this glass, Fonny trying to hold it together, but...

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Get me out of here, baby. Get me out of here, please.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I promise, baby, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I yelled. I wasn't yelling at you.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (a tear forming) I know.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Please don't cry. Please don't cry... it's bad for the baby. (and a smile now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make they skin all wrinkled, come out lookin’ like a old man, be givin’ birth to a baby Red Foxx. 49. Something between a laugh and a cry at that, tear and the laugh at once:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: That’s right, give us a smile. Tish wiping another tear, composing herself, a nice smile

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Is that all right?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You can do better than that. Tish sticking out her tongue, crossing her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Is this better?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you nut, give us a kiss. Tish’s palm to her lips, placed flat against the glass. F meeting it with his palm, then carrying it back to his li

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You still love me?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I'll always love you.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I love you, baby. I miss you. I miss everything about you, I miss everything we had together, everything we did together, walking and talking and making love; baby, get me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I will. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I promise. You take care of yourself out there.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I will Fonny, you know I will.  50. Fonny raising his fist to the glass, Tish meeting it. CUT TO BLACK. “Fonny had been walking down Seventh Avenue when he ran i Daniel. They had not seen each other since their days at vocational school.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny and the aforementioned DANIEL standing on the sidew A lot of laughing and high-fiving from the two but we don hear any of it, instead, Tish’s narration: “Time had not improved Daniel."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “He was still big, black, and loud; at the age of twenty- three, a little older than Fonny, but he was already runn out of familiar faces. So... they grabbed each other on t avenue.”

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Wow! What's happenin’?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Why you asking me, man?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Because, like the man says about Mt. Everest: ‘You're there.’ Fonny laughing at that, we can quickly tell he loves this cat.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Come on. We got some beer at the pad. You remember Tish?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Skinny little Tish?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's still my girl. We going to get married, man. Come on and let me show you the pad. And she'll fix us something to eat, I told you we got beer at the house. Fonny throwing a hand behind Daniel’s neck jovially.  51. “And though he certainly shouldn't be spending the money, pushes Daniel into a cab and they roll on down to Bank Street: where I am not expecting them."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish looking on with surprise as Fonny and Daniel push in the apartment still laughing their asses off.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Daniel and Tish exchanging hugs of greeting, Fonny gestur and explaining this run in but, again, we hear none of it instead: “But I could not be indifferent to Daniel because I reali from Fonny's face, how marvelous it was for him to have scooped up from the swamp waters of his past, an old frie

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. BANK STREET —- DAY - MOVING Moving with Tish as she walks along the sidewalk, shoppin bag at her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Fonny with fresh beers before them. A record player going, Les McCann’s "Compared To What” playing as two squat on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (both wishful and mocking) So, you really going to get married?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, we looking for a place to live; we looking for a loft because that don't cost no whole lot of bread, you know, and that way I can work without Tish being bugged to death. This room ain't big enough for one, ain't no question about its being big enough for two, and I got all my work here and in the basement. Fonny rolling a cigarette as he speaks:  52.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: They got lofts standing empty all over the East Side, man, and don't nobody want to rent them, except freaks like me. And they all fire traps and some of them ain't even got no toilets. So, you figure like finding a loft ain't going to be no sweat. He lights the cig, takes a drag, and hands it to Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: But man, this country really do not like niggers. They do not like niggers so bad, man, they will rent to a leper first, I swear. Daniel drags on the cigarette, hands it back to Fonny, wh drags on it, takes a sip of his beer and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Sometimes Tish and I go together, sometimes she goes alone, sometimes I go alone. But it's always the same story, man. And now I can't let her go alone no more because, dig, last week we thought we had us a loft, the cat had promised it to her. But he had not seen me. And he figures a black chick by herself, way downtown looking for a loft, well, he know he going to make it with her. He thinks she's propositioning him, that's what he really thinks. And she comes to tell me — just so proud and happy — and we go on over there. And when the cat sees me, he says there's been some great misunderstanding, he can't rent the loft because he's got all these relatives coming in from Rumania like in half an hour and he got to give it to them. Shit. And I told him he was full of shit and he threatened to call the cops on my ass. Fonny looking away, up at that small window looking up ou the sidewalk from this low vantage:  53.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (to himself) I'm really going to have to try to figure out some way of getting some bread together and getting out of this fucking country.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: How you going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. (beat) Tish can't swim. Fonny and Daniel whoop and rock with laughter. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (soberly) Maybe you could go first.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Nah. (and) I don't think I want to do that. I'd be too scared.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Scared of what? A long, long beat. The cigarette and the record are finis There’s nothing to hide behind.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Just scared.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Scared of what might happen to Tish?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then) Scared of what might happen to both of us - without each other. Like Tish ain't got no sense at all, man, she trusts everybody. She walk down the street, swinging that little behind of hers, and she's surprised, man, when some cat tries to jump her. She don't see the world like everybody see it.  54. And silence falls again, Daniel watching Fonny:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I know I might seem to be a weird kind of cat. But I got two things in my life, man - I got my wood and stone and I got Tish. If I lose them, I'm lost. I know that. You know, whatever's in me I didn't put there. And I can't take it out.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don't know if you so weird. I know you lucky. I ain't got nothing like that. Can I have another beer, man?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Hell yeah you can. Fonny up and over at the icebox, opens two more cans. Han one to Daniel, Daniel taking a long swallow, goes dark:

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I just come out the slammer, baby. Two years. They said — they still say — I stole a car. Man, I can't even drive a car, and I tried to make my lawyer - but he was really their lawyer, dig - prove that. And, anyway, I wasn't in no car when they picked me up. But I had a little grass on me. I was on my stoop. And so they come and picked me up, you know, it was about midnight, and they locked me up and then the next morning they put me in the lineup and somebody said it was me stole the car, that car I ain't seen yet. And so, you know, since I had that weed on me, they had me anyhow and so they said if I would plead guilty they'd give me a lighter sentence. If I didn't plead guilty, they'd throw me the book. Well... (sips that beer) ...I was alone, baby, wasn't nobody, and so I entered the guilty plea. Two years! Daniel leans forward, gets closer to Fonny.  55.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But, then, it sounded a whole lot better than the marijuana charge. He leans back and laughs and sips his beer, looks at Fonn

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Two God damn years!

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: By the balls. The loudest and longest silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: ..-Fonny and Daniel still sitting on the floor, but their countenance shifted, suspended along the path running fro apathy to defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish in the kitchenette there, preparing a meal as Fonny Daniel continue their talk in the main room.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: How long you been out?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: About three months. (and) Man, it was bad. Very bad. And it's bad now. Maybe I'd feel different if I had done something and got caught. But I didn't do nothing. They were just playing with me, man, because they could. And I'm lucky it was only two years, you dig? Because they can do with you whatever they want. Whatever they want. And they dogs, man. I really found out, in the slammer, what Malcolm and them cats was talking about. The white man's got to be the devil. He sure ain't a man. Some of the things I saw... I'll be dreaming about until the day I die. Fonny puts one hand on Daniel's neck.  56.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: That's alright, man. You out now, it's over, you young.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Man, I know what you're saying. And I appreciate it. But you don't know, the worst thing, man, the worst thing, is that they can make you so fucking scared. Just... scared, man. Tish in that kitchen, clearly listening to the whole thin right in here with them.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (calling out) You cats hungry?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (joking) Yeah, we starvin’. Move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them caught mid-laugh, gathered around the l wood table in this space. A few open bottles of beer abou And little Tish has made a feast: ribs and cornbread and rice, gravy and green peas.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
