dialogues.text: It's nice to see you, Tish. You sure ain't gained no weight, have you?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: You hush. I'm skinny because I'm poor.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, I sure don't know why you didn't pick yourself a rich husband. You ain't never going to gain no weight now.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Well, if you skinny, Daniel, you can move faster and when you in a tight place, you got a better chance of getting out of it. You see what I mean?  57.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You sound like you got it figured. You learn all that from Fonny? (at Fonny) Maybe she can't gain no weight, but you sure will. You folks mind if I drop by more often?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Feel free. (winks at Tish) Tish ain't very good looking, but she can sure get the pots together.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I'm happy to know I have some use. Tish curling her lips at Fonny across the table. He smile starts chewing on a rib. They all do, letting the talk subside for a beat as they enjoy this meal, then... .+.-Fonny and Tish locking eyes across the table, absent Daniel, away from Daniel and... “In complete silence, without moving a muscle, we are laughing with each other. We are together somewhere where one can reach us, joined."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .--alternating, both of them looking directly at_us as Ti continues: “We are happy, even, that we have food enough for Daniel, eats peacefully, not knowing that we are laughing, but sensing that something wonderful has happened to us... wh means that wonderful things happen... and that maybe something wonderful will happen... to him.” CUT TO BLACK. And OVER BLACK, the sound of footsteps, hollow and reverberating, as though echoing down a long, slender hal As these footsteps continue to sound... ...a figure taking shape, like shoulders, the silhouette something. The entire image brightening now as, at the end of this hallway, a point of light emanating from the center. Those shoulders approaching the light, as they near it, another sound rising, most similar to a wail; a child's w  58. The shoulders moving with more purpose now, picking up sp furiously attempting to reach that light. A wall of noise, the clatter of feet in this hallway, the ever present wail and, that point of light, no matter how fast we move or how loud those footsteps, never growing closer, an infinite, futile scramble as...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: ...standing above us, a wet towel in her hand, the look o her face one of concern. INT. TISH’S HOME, BEDROOM - NIGHT Tish’s eyes closed, heavily asleep. But her body clinched with tension, hand gripping at the sheet, feet kicking atop the covers. A guttural, muted sound rising from Tish’s chest as Sharo sits to the bed beside her, gently lays a hand to Tish’s brow, caresses her head. Slowly, Tish’s eyes opening, drifting into consciousness. Sharon dabs the wet towel at Tish’s temples, looks down a her lovingly:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I know I can't help you very much right now - God knows what I wouldn't give if I could. But I know about suffering; if that helps. I know that it ends. I ain't going to tell you no lies, like it always ends for the better. Sometimes it ends for the worse. You can suffer so bad that you can be driven to a place where you can't ever suffer again: and that's worse. Sharon setting that towel down, taking Tish’s hands and enveloping them in her own.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Try to remember that. And: the only way anything ever gets done is when you make up your mind to do it. I know a lot of our men have died in prison: but not all of them. You remember that.  59.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you ain't really alone in that bed. You got that child beneath your heart and we're all counting on you, Fonny's counting on you, to bring that child here safe and well. You the only one who can do it. But you're strong. Lean on your strength. (and) You understand?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Are you all right now? Can you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I don't want to sound foolish. But remember, love brought you here. If you trusted love this far, don't panic now, trust it all the way. Sharon leans down, kisses her daughter on the forehead. Another caress with that towel then she rises, heads for door. Turns off the light behind her as we...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: .-.and brighter, Tish waking in bed, having slept through night. INT. TISH’S HOME, KITCHEN - DAY Tish dressed now, Ernestine already at the dining table thumbing through some paperwork, Sharon at the counter pouring a cup of coffee as Tish enters.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Hey, Jezebel. Tish sticking her tongue out at her sister as she passes, comes up behind Sharon and gives her mother a hug. “Sis started calling me Jezebel after I got my job at the perfume counter. She said..."  60.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (with a wicked smile) You smell like a Louisiana whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time we’ve seen Tish take the train by herself. Crowded as the car is, she’s incredibly alone. And visibl pregnant. “The store thought that it was very progressive to give t job to a colored girl."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering hurriedly through the main show-floor with Tish, passing her coworkers — her white coworkers — as she hust to clock in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish a bit more “made-up,” standing behind the perfume counter. “I stand behind that counter all day long, smiling till m back teeth ache." As we draw closer to Tish, see the strain to keep that outward face... “And it isn't only old white ladies who come to that coun to smell the back of my hand.” QUICK VIGNETTE: Tish and an aforementioned Old White lady Tish’s smile false as the color of this women’s wig. “Very rarely does a black cat come anywhere near this counter, and if he does, his intentions are often more generous and always more precise." QUICK VIGNETTE: Tish at the counter, one of the aforementioned “Black Cats” approaching the perfume count but not stopping, moves past it with a cautionary look th Tish’s way. “Perhaps for a black cat, I look like a helpless baby sis And he doesn't want to see me turn into a whore." QUICK VIGNETTE: Tish behind the counter as a different “B Cat” approaches, comes right up to the counter.  61. “And yet some black cats come closer, just to look into m eyes, to check out what's happenin’. And they never smell back of my hand.” QUICK IMAGE SERIES: Just as Tish describes it... “A black cat puts out his hand, and you spray it, and he carries the back of his own hand to his own nostrils."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TISH
dialogues.text: At the counter as a plain, middle-everything white man approaches. “But a white man?”

dialogues.speaker: QUICK IMAGE SERIES
dialogues.text: Just as Tish describes it... “A white man will take your hand, he will carry your fles his nostrils... and he will hold it there.” Hold on this image, and on Tish looking without feeling, forced smile to obscure, then... “He will hold it there for a lifetime."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish and Ernestine together in a corner of this dive, Tis still dressed from work. Kind of place where two women wanting to be left alone are afforded that wish.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Well don’t you smell nice. Off Tish’s rolled eyes:

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: You want the good news or the bad news first?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Bad news.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: See that’s how you know we family. (and) Bad news is, they found Mrs. Rogers, she’s in Santurce, Puerto Rico. Somebody’s gonna have to go there to talk to her.  62.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Which we'll have to pay for. A nod yes from Ernestine.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Okay, what’s the good news?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: That... they found her, I guess?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: How she get to Puerto Rico? Ernestine shrugging, a sip of her beer:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I can’t go to Puerto Rico. Another look from Ernestine, more biting: obviously.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: So Hayward?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Hayward's got to deal with Bell and the DA. Anyway, you can see that, for many, many reasons, Hayward can't go. He'd be accused of intimidating a witness.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: But that's what they're doing--

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: It would take us until your baby is voting age to prove that. Look, mama and Daddy don't know, I haven't talked to them yet, wanted to talk to you first. Tish nodding at that, taking it all in. She goes cold:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Do you think she really was raped?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Tish... I don't know what's going on in that ingrown mind of yours, but that question has no bearing on anything. As far as our situation is concerned baby, she was raped. That's it.  Ernestine takes a sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: I think, in fact, that she was raped and that she has absolutely no idea who did it, would probably not even recognize him if he passed her on the street. I may sound crazy, but the mind works that way. She'd recognize him if he raped her again. But then it would no longer be rape, if you see what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I see what you mean. But why Fonny?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Because he was presented to her as the rapist and it was much easier to say yes than to try and relive the whole damn thing again. This way, it's over for her. Except for the trial. But then... it's really over, for her.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: And for us, too?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: No. Not even. It won't be over for us. 63. Tish taking a beat before this next part, fixes Ernestine her sights:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: What about Puerto Rico?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: That's one of the reasons I wanted to talk to you. Before we talk to Mama and Daddy. Look. You can't go, no way you can. For one thing, without you, Fonny will panic. I don't see how I can go, I've got to keep lighting firecrackers under Hayward's ass. Daddy can't go, and God knows Frank can't go. That leaves Mama.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Mama? A nod from Ernestine:  64.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: She don't want to go to Puerto Rico.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: And she hates planes. But she wants your baby's father out of jail. She'll go.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: And what do you think she can do?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: She can do something no special investigator can do: she may be able to break through to Mrs. Rogers. Maybe not, but if she can, we're ahead. And if not, well, we haven't lost anything, and at least we'll know we've tried.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: And what about Daniel? Daniel can vouch for us, Daniel knows Fonny was with him.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: I told you. Hayward is seeing him tomorrow. He may have been able to see him today. Tish nodding it all in, confirming it all in her head.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Some shit.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But we in it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish and Ernestine on the corner here, Ernestine throwing arm around Tish, the kid sister leaning into her. They begin down the sidewalk this way, supporting one another. As they reach the corner, the sisters turn but.. ...we continue across the intersection, moving along the crosswalk over lanes of traffic. Across this intersection, another pub there, as much a di as the one we’ve just left. As we near it, its open doors invite us into...  65. INT. 8TH AVE BERNIE’S - DAY - MOVING - CONTINUOUS Drifting through this place, lot of regulars at the bar nursing sad drinks. As we take it all in, a pair of familiar faces appearing there in the back: Joe and Frank, each nursing what appea be rocked up whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Well, the first thing we got to do is to stop blaming ourselves. If we can't do that, man, we'll never get the boy out because we'll be so fucked up. And we cannot fuck up now, baby, and I know you hear where I'm coming from.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I hear that but man, what we going to do about the money?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You ever have any money? Frank looks up at him and says nothing, merely questions with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You ever have any money?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Then why you worried about it now? Frank looks up at him again.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You raised them somehow. You fed them somehow, didn't you? If we start to worrying about money now, man, we going to be fucked and we going to lose our children. That white man, baby, he want you to be worried about the money. That's his whole game. But if we got to where we are without money, we can get further.  66.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain't worried about they money -- they ain't got no right to it anyhow, they stole it from us -- they ain't never met nobody they didn't lie to and steal from. Well, I can steal, too. And rob. How you think I raised my daughters? Shit. But Frank is not Joseph. He stares down again, into his drink.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What you think is going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: What we make happen!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s easy to say.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Not if you mean it. There is a long silence into which neither man speaks. Ev the jukebox is silent.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I guess... I love Fonny more than I love anybody in this world. And it makes me ashamed, man, I swear, because he was a real manly little boy, wasn't scared of nothing, except maybe his Mama. He didn't understand his Mama. And I don't know what I should’ve done. I ain't a woman. And there's some things only a woman can do with a child. Frank sips his drink, tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know if I was ever any kind of father to him — any kind of real father — and now he's in jail and it ain't his fault and I don't even know how I'm going to get him out. I'm sure one hell of a man.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Well, he sure think you are. He loves you, and he respects you; now you got to remember that I might know that better than you.  67.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell you something else: your son is the father of my daughter's baby. Now, how you going to sit here and act like can't nothing be done? We got a child on the way here, man. You want me to beat the shit out of you? He says this with ferocity but, after a moment, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Now I know some hustles and you know some hustles and these are our children and we got to set them free. So, let's drink up man and go on in. We got a whole lot of shit to deal with in a hurry. CUT TO BLACK. “The date for Fonny's trial keeps changing. This fact, of course, forces me to realize that Hayward's concern is genuine." INT. HAYWARD’S OFFICE - DAY - MONTAGE 3 Hayward standing behind his desk, looking down on stacks stacks of paperwork. “I don't think that he very much cared in the beginning. never taken a case like Fonny's before, but once into it, odor of shit rose too high; he had no choice but to keep stirring it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayward caressing a snifter of cognac surrounded by other lawyer types, a good old boy feel to it... with Hayward appearing out of place. “It became obvious at once, for example, that the degree his concern for his client placed him at odds with the keepers of the keys and seals."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “He had not expected this and at first it bewildered... t frightened and angered him." INT. TISH’S HOME - NIGHT - MONTAGE 3 The family engaged in what appears to be a spirited discussion, inaudible the whole of it, all Tish:  68. “It didn't help that I distrusted him, Ernestine harangue him, Mama was laconic and, for Joseph, he was just anothe white boy with a college degree."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish looking substantially more pregnant than we’ve seen previously. “And so... mama begins letting out my clothes and I go to work wearing jackets and slacks."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernestine sitting before a well appointed desk in the foy of the most monied domicile we’1ll see all film, a young, pretty white woman pacing before her. “Ernestine has taken a second job as part-time secretary rich and eccentric actress whose connections she intends intimidate and use."

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SPLIT SCREEN: the docks on one side, the garment district the other. “And Joseph and Frank are coldly, systemically stealing f the docks and the garment center, selling the hot goods i Harlem or in Brooklyn."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Joe standing at the rear doors of a van we've n seen before, the two of them in conversation with other m as they gesture into the bed of the van. “They don't tell me any of this, of course. But I know it I know it.” CUT TO BLACK. And OVER BLACK, a new SOUND rising, like the city through window, distant and present at once. “I remember the night the baby was conceived. It was the day we found our loft.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny and Tish with a third man we’ve not seen before (LE tall, lanky, white).  69. “It was off Canal Street and it was big and in good condition.” QUICK IMAGE: Levy showing Tish and Fonny the loft. “There was a room for Fonny to work and, with all the win open, you wouldn't die of heat stroke in the summer." QUICK IMAGE: Tish and Fonny with Levy gazing out over the city from the industrial roof of the place. “Levy only wanted one month's rent for deposit. When he t us, I thought Fonny would have a heart attack.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them spilling onto the sidewalk. Tish instinctively taking Fonny’s hand as Levy sizes them up.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the neighbors. After five or six o'clock, you won't have any. All you got down here is sweatshops; place on the ground floor is legit. (and) Any questions? Levy looking from Tish to Fonny, expectant. The two of th dumbfounded, no telling how many places they’ve seen at t point, none of them yielding this result.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: What’s the catch?

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: How you mean? Fonny pausing a moment, debating, then...

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: No offense Levy, but we been lookin’ a long time. Don’t seem to me like it’s a reason for you to treat two Negros so nice like, clearly we ain’t got a pot nor much of a drink to make piss with; pardon my French. Levy looking away from Fonny here, briefly at Tish and th for just a moment, at their hands joined there.  70.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: You got two weeks to make the deposit. After that, no promises. Fonny pulling Tish into his side, the two of them lovely together. And from the look on Levy’s face, fatherly, thi loveliness exactly why the place will be their's.

dialogues.speaker: LEVY
dialogues.text: Keep in touch about getting that deposit together, you hear? A nod from Fonny, earnest.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Will do, Levy. Will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking with Tish and Fonny, this path from Soho to the Village. Twilight out, the sun falling, that energy in the street the day is ending; and peacefully. It would be a Friday, feel of the eminent weekend and all that it promises. A quiet, lazy pace these two, Tish leaned into Fonny as s wont to do. No place in particular to hurry to; what else could possibly matter? A beat of this walking then... Fonny stops; no reason, ju stops walking mid-stride. Looks to the ground, and then t the sky. Throws his head back and shouts, yells to the heavens. He’s still holding Tish’s hand. And from the smile on his face, this is a joyous shout. Tish looking into his face, the smile now spreading to he Not a word spoken between them. Without thinking, Tish th her head back as well, shouts the same as Fonny. Those smiles wider between them as they pick up their wal again, looking from one to the other. Tish catching Fonny eye. Throws her head back once more and, again, yells to the s Fonny stops, takes Tish by the hand, pulls her into him, hand to her chin, speaks softly:  71.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You ready for this?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. (and) Ain’t nothin’ else in the world I'm more ready for. Fonny smiling, big, bright, a child’s face. He is as happ any man could be. They're walking again, approaching a corner up ahead, an intersection with a small grocer on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I’m gonna grab some tomatoes for dinner. A delay from Fonny, just watching her. Leans over to kiss on the forehead:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I’m’a grab me some smokes across the street. Fonny splitting off, moving into the crosswalk, a small c shop just across the way. We stay here with Tish, continuing on this little ways, another ten feet and we're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish standing near the entrance of this place, a selectio produce set just onto the sidewalk. She's at the tomato stand, rummaging through it when we h

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can sure dig a tomato who digs tomatoes. Tish turning to that voice, finds herself face to face wi small, greasy ITALIAN PUNK. His hand on Tish, caressing her behind. He licks his lips smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN PUNK
dialogues.text: Hey, sweet tomato. You know I dig tomatoes.  72. And now people are watching. Tish searching them, looking help but people only stare, no one moves. Tish goes to move past him, leaves the tomatoes there but boy grabs her arm. Instinctively, she slaps him — BAP! — spits in his face. And at this moment, Fonny enters the store, grabs the boy the hair, knocks him to the ground and kicks him somethin fierce. Takes him by the lapel and drags him out onto the sidewalk, tosses him in the gutter. Tish screaming and, at first, we’re not sure why, Tish grabbing a hold of Fonny and, oddly, turning her back to Fonny’s chest, reaches behind her and pulls him close to his chin at the crown of her head. And then we see him: a uniformed officer hurrying across intersection, eyes flaring, billy-club at the ready. As he nears, we recognize him: this is the aforementioned blue-eyed officer from Tish’s remembrances, OFFICER BELL. Tish holding the back of her head against Fonny's chest, his wrists clutched in her two hands.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (to Bell, frantic) That man there attacked me. Right in this store. Right now. Every- body saw it. No one says a word. Bell looking at them all, still staring but nobody speaki Then he looks back at Tish. And Fonny. There is no pity i Bell’s face.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: (at Fonny) And where were you, while all this... Bell’s eyes drifting over Tish in exactly the same way th boy's had...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: .»-while all this was going on between junior there and your girl?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: He was around the corner, buying cigarettes.  73.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: Is that so, boy? Tish’s body jerking as Fonny’s hands clench in her grasp:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (sharp) He's not a boy, Officer. Bell taking another look at Tish and Fonny as someone in crowd gets the Italian Punk to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: You live around here? The back of Tish’s head is still on Fonny's chest, but he released his wrists from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Yes, on Bank Street. 1906 Bank Street.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: We're going to take you down, boy, for assault and battery.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh no you're not. Tish, Fonny, Bell, everyone’s eyes going to the shop now, small, elderly ITALIAN LADY standing there with one hand her hip, the other pointing sharply at Bell:

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN LADY
dialogues.text: I know both these young people. They shop here very often. What the young lady has told you is the truth. I saw them both when they came, and I watched her choose her tomatoes and her young man left her and he said he would be right back. I was busy, I could not get to her right away; her tomatoes are still on the scale. And that little good- for-nothing over there attacked her. What would you do if a man attacked your wife? If you have one. The crowd snickers. Bell flushes.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN LADY
dialogues.text: I saw exactly what happened. I ama witness. And I will swear to it.  74.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: Funny way to run a business.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN LADY
dialogues.text: You will not tell me how to run my business. I was on this street before you got here and I will be here long after you are gone. The Italian lady reenters the store and takes Tish’s toma off the scale and puts them in a bag.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: (to Fonny) Well... .--be seeing you around.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You may... ..-and then again, you may not. A beat of these two holding eyes as the crowd disperses. There’s a dark, heavy promise in these eyes. It runs both ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish and Fonny heading back the way they came. Fonny holds the bag of tomatoes in the crook of one arm; other arm he entwines through Tish’s. They walk slowly.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Tish...

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Don't ever try to protect me again.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: But you were trying to protect me.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (heavy; quiet) It's not... ...the same... .--thing. Fonny takes the bag of tomatoes... and smashes them again the nearest wall. They make a beautiful, chiaroscuro mess streaking red. But, mercifully, they hardly make a sound.  75. The two of them standing apart now, Fonny with his hands his pockets, looking down at his feet, disgusted. Tish with a hand covering her mouth, the other wrapped ab herself. Fonny closing the space, takes her hand in his:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Don't think I don't know you love me. You believe we going to make it? Tish embracing him, a hand to his cheek, a very full kiss She draws back, starts to say something, but... he puts a finger to her lips. Smiles his little smile.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Hush. Don't say a word. I'm going to take you out to dinner. At our Spanish place, you remember? Tish nodding yes, holds his gaze. A beat of this, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny and Tish escorted to their table in Pedrocito’s restaurant, holding hands as they follow him.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: We have no money, but we are very hungry. And I will have some money in a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: In a couple of days, that is what they all say! And, furthermore, I suppose that you would like to eat sitting down!

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Why, yes, if you could arrange it, that would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: (over shoulder) And now, no doubt, you would like two margheritas?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: (as he sits) Caught me again.  76. A wink and a laugh from Pedrocito as he disappears into t rear of this place. Fonny takes Tish’s hand atop the tabl there. All eyes; holding eyes, speaking with eyes, loving with e And from this look, a plea, a promise, a thirst within...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny and Tish on the palette, making love. No need for any details beyond this: making love, making all the way to and through the point of release, Tish hol on to Fonny, keeping him here, keeping him in. Both their breaths subsiding after the act, Fonny’s mouth close at Tish’s ear, all whispers and...

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Tish. (and) Oh Tish. CUT TO BLACK. “We are beginning to have a somewhat acrid dialogue, this thing and I." INT. TISH’S HOME, KITCHEN - DAY Tish standing at the stove, preparing a simple meal, by t looks of her belly, very pregnant, a sign of the present.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK IMAGE SERIES
dialogues.text: Just as Tish describes it... “It kicks, and I smash an egg on the floor." ANGLE ON: egg hitting the kitchen floor. “It kicks, and suddenly the coffeepot is upside down on t table.” ANGLE ON: coffee spilling across the dining table, Ernest jumping to avoid the burn as Tish doubles over. “It kicks, and the perfume on the back of my hand brings to the roof of my mouth and my free hand weighs on the gl counter with force enough to crack it in two."  77. ANGLE ON: Tish at the perfume counter, doubled over in pa as a coworker rushes over.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Goddammit! (and sotto) Be patient. I'm doing the best I can. Please. Tish gripping that perfume counter again, a guttural grun “And then it hauls off again, like Muhammad Ali, and I'm the ropes." INT. TISH’S HOME - NIGHT Empty, at least visually so, just the furniture and a mut light from the kitchen hitting the floor. That hallway running towards the bedrooms directly before empty like the rest of this place. And yet, a sound echoi off the floors and walls here. Distinct: it’s the sound of vomiting. A beat more of this sound and then a toilet flushing, run water. A moment later... ...Tish appears, clutching her stomach and forehead at on approaching down that hall, holding onto the wall as she goes, moves past us and turns for the dining table. Sits and, within moments, Joseph appearing from just insi the kitchen, had no idea he was there, sets down a warm m of something, a wedge of lemon and bottle of honey beside He takes a seat opposite her, watches as she squeezes the lemon into the water, hangs her head over that cup a beat His eyes, all sympathy: he’d carry it himself if he could

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny alone at the glass this time, phone at the ready, looking on as Tish waddles across the room.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Here she come! Big as two houses! Tish smiling as she sits to a stool, one of the few insta she won't mind folks calling out her weight.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You sure it ain’t twins? Or triplets?  78.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shit eating grin) Shit, we might make history. Fonny throwing back his head at his own joke, laughing lo enough the sound travels through that glass.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (at her belly) Your daddy figure hisself a comedian. Fonny calming, smiles at his love.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You look good baby.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Thank you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Better than anybody over here, don’t care how big you get.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Well as soon as that ain’t the truth somethin’ wrong, you tell me ‘cause I’m outta here then. Tish settles on her stool there, head lolling slightly to side. She’s relaxed now. And in that relaxed state, takes in, sees him better:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: How you doin’, husband?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I'm good, wife. (and) You here now. I’m all good now. You know I love you.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: You know I love you. A nod from Fonny.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No matter what happen with all of this sh-- Tish’s hand going to the glass, palm flat, the stool scoo back as she leans forward, all her weight going there.  79. Fonny shocked, his hand going to the glass as he shoots upright, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I'm alright.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Tish.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I’m okay. She looks up, manages a smile, a smile streaked through w pain and clipped breaths. Fonny’s hand still on the glass, was aligned perfectly wi Tish’s. Hers removed now, always a lady: smoothing her ha looks to the guard who’s appeared over her left shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (at guard) I’m okay. (and at Fonny) I’m fine. Fonny settling, something about this moment revelatory fo him, the physical evidence of things he’d only assumed before. If that.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Me? I’m not the one just got punched by a midget inside they belly. Tish and Fonny holding eyes a beat. A second beat. A third beat, and, finally... Tish cracking, a smile at t corner of her lips and then, a laugh, a hand to her belly support the shaking and now, an all-out gutbuster of a la Fonny doing the same on the other side of that glass, the of them laughing so hard together the others around them, both sides of the glass, noticing. The couple holding eyes as the laugh subsides, even as it fades the presence of it steady, all there in the lines a the corner of their mouths, same smiles they’ve exchanged since bathing together as kids.  80. Hold here a beat, a noticeable beat. If they never have another moment, they'll have had this. And like every mom it’ll have all been worth it. CUT TO BLACK. “Mama gets to Puerto Rico on an evening plane."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A majestic, period-appropriate Pan-Am jet freshly parked the runway, unloading directly to the tarmac. Dozens of travelers in some form of deplaning, descending down portable stairs. Just a beat of this to recognize Sharon de-boarding among the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the first frame: loud, a cacophony of voices pushing aggressive brand of Spanish in here. Families and their m possessions throughout this space, few people talking, everyone shouting. With her overly done-up clothes and hair, Sharon sticking out, the darkest, most American figure in view. We find h at the front of a line, engaged with an AIRPORT STAFFER.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Do you speak English? A smile from the staffer, friendly, but no answer.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but I don’t speak any Spanish and I’ve had to come here unexpectedly. And I don’t drive, you see? More silence from Victoria and, it must be noted: for a b woman raised in the Jim Crow South, this one of the few moments in Sharon’s life she can be said to emit privileg

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (desperate) You see?

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT STAFFER
dialogues.text: One moment Sefiora. Sharon waiting, watching as the girl rounds this Hertz de moves off into the throng.  81. Watching her as Sharon does, we get a good look at the terminal: many peoples of various shades — and all atop o another, hard to breathe — with all the possessions they could carry here staged without the promise of leaving or going, just... here.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sefiora... Sharon turning, finds the airport staffer approaching, a humble boy of about eighteen following close.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT STAFFER
dialogues.text: This is Jaime, your driver, he will take you to your hotel, tell him. Sharon digging into her small clutch, retrieves a small p of paper and hands it to the boy. He meets her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: It will be my pleasure, Sefiora. INT. JAIME’S CAB - NIGHT - MOVING Sharon in the backseat, staring out at this alien landsca the sound of the paved but worn road beneath them. She and Jaime eyeing each other in the rearview, each of on the sly. Nervous, curious. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: It is okay, Sefiora. You are safe with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon’s suitcase atop the bed, its contents spilled over Takes a moment to take it all in. Reaches down and grabs item: a stylish, Cotton Club-esque hat. Turns to the mirror behind her, sizes herself up, puts on hat. Indifferent. Sharon takes the hat off, comes back to reflection again. She’s thinking, considering. She puts the hat on again. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a beat here with Sharon and the mirrored elevator do  82. She's staring into her own eyes. She is not wearing that INT. JAIME’S CAB - NIGHT - MOVING More sound, more jostling at these worn roads. Sharon looks... ridiculous, like the American tourist she is ina club dress and black shawl wrapped about her head. More eyes in that rearview, from Jaime that same curiosit When Sharon meets his gaze this time, neither looks away.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Thank you for waiting.

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: Of course, Sefiora. I will take you wherever you wish and wait for as long as you like. Sharon holding this boy’s eyes in the rearview, dumbstruc The air thick with something, chaste, a connection. Out the window, every now and then what’s best described shanty-town arising in the distance. A small flame, a sin light. The sound of the car’s movement wed to these image then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon standing in the foyer of a San Juan Resort Hotel, lobby behind her, entrance of the subterranean nightclub before her. The entry to the club runs clear through to a dance-floor the lip of the dancefloor a raised band-stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon sitting alone in a nightclub booth, the music loud now, much more ridiculous, a Puerto Rican cover of someth wild and propulsive. Sharon taking in the scene. It’s early, not many people i this place, the other booths mostly empty. A man approach now, a clear cocktail held aloft.

dialogues.speaker: SERVER
dialogues.text: Your drink Sefiorita.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Thank you. And as the man turns to move away:  83.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: SERVER
dialogues.text: Yes, Sefiorita? The man stepping closer.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Well... I’m supposed to meet a friend here, but the flight I meant to take was overbooked, so I was forced to take an earlier one, I’m not sure he’s here yet.

dialogues.speaker: SERVER
dialogues.text: Who is your friend?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: It’s actually more the nature of business. I’m waiting for Sefior Alvarez; Pietro Alvarez. I’m Mrs. Rivers. From New York. A reaction from the server. Clearly something Sharon said struck a chord.

dialogues.speaker: SERVER
dialogues.text: Yes, Seflorita. I will tell Sefior Alvarez. The man leaves. Sharon takes up her screwdriver, downs th balance of one half it. Beat. Sharon waits. In this waiting, a realization: this is the first time Sharon’s been alone in a very long time. By herself at this booth, an older woman, a black, American woman, so alien to this place. Sharon reaching into her clutch, retrieves a tasteful com looking contraption, it’s contents a surprise: a row of immaculate Virginia Slims. As she brings the first cig to her lips, lights it:

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You Mrs. Rivers? (and) You waiting for me?  84. Sharon looking up from that cig, a slender, Latino man wi strained mustache standing before her. This is PIETRO, Victoria's boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Pietro? Pietro Alvarez?

dialogues.speaker: PIETRO
dialogues.text: Maybe. What you want to see him about?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I don’t especially want to see Mr. Alvarez. I want to see Victoria Rogers. I’m the mother-in-law of the man she’s accused of rape. Pietro shifting at that, Sharon the last person he assume would walk into his club tonight. He takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: PIETRO
dialogues.text: Well lady, you got one hell of a son-in-law, let me tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I also have one hell of a daughter, let me tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: PIETRO
dialogues.text: Look, she’s been through enough; More than enough. Leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: A man is about to die for something he didn’t do, can we leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Another drink, Sefor Alvarez? Both Sharon and Pietro looking up at that, the server returned.

dialogues.speaker: PIETRO
dialogues.text: It’s on me, give the lady what she wants. And give me the usual. On the bandstand, the Puerto Rican rockers launch into Es Bien Mi Nena. The server moves away.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Do you believe I love my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly lady, it’s hard to believe you got a daughter. 85. That said as a come-on. To her shock, Sharon is empathizi with Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Do you think I would marry my daughter to a rapist?

dialogues.speaker: PIETRO
dialogues.text: You might not know.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Son, listen: I know that she was raped, and I know... I know what women know. But I also know that Alonzo did not rape her.

dialogues.speaker: PIETRO
dialogues.text: Why you comin’ to me? Shit, I ain’t nothin’: Indian, wop, spic, spade, that’s me baby. I got my little thing here and I got Victoria and lady, I don’t want to put her through no more shit, I’m sorry. Pietro pushing back from the table:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: No, please. Sharon grabbing a hold of Pietro’s hand. With her free hand, Sharon reaching into her clutch, digg frantically. Retrieves a photo from there, a photo of Fon and Tish, thrusts it toward Pietro.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Look at them. (and) Look at them. The music louder, more propulsive now, those kids on the bandstand letting into that song.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Take this photo home; take it to Victoria. Take it and you ask her, you show it to her and you ask her, ask her to study it. Hold her in your arms; do that.  86.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m a woman, I know what women know, I know that she was raped. But I also know, I know that Alonzo did not rape her; I know it. Beat. Not a long beat though — a quick one — just enough for Pi to glance at that photo, then at Sharon’s desperate face. Closes his eyes, and... ...-releases his hand from Sharon’s, leaves that photo wi her as he disappears across the dance-floor. Off Sharon watching him go, defeated, broken and embarras all at once...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaime waiting, pops to attention as... ..».-Sharon approaches, blows right past him, shocks him marches on. Jaime frozen to the spot, watches as Sharon reaches the gravel lot, plumes of light dust behind her, reaches the cab and lets herself into the back seat. Jaime watching his cab for a beat, unsure what to do. Slo tentatively, he begins towards the cab. Reaches the passengers side door and... stops. INT. JAIME’S CAB - NIGHT - SAME Sharon in the backseat here. Slouched down, cradled into herself, sobbing. Jaime outside the window, allowing her this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright, bright daylight, peaceful and quiet. Sharon gazin out of her hotel window at Puerto Rican sun. Below her, in the parking lot, that familiar cab and Jaim “When Mama wakes in the morning, Jaime is there waiting f her. She has become his responsibility because, as the ma said about Mt. Everest: ‘You're there.'" INT. JAIME’S CAB - DAY - MOVING The sound of rough gravel beneath tires, Sharon looking o the window of Jaime’s cab at the passing slum.  87. Desolate out there, the San Juan found between resort tow a cross between rural, hood and everything in between. A beat of travel, then:

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: I think it might be here. You say she is blond, yes? Sharon nodding, focusing on the slum appearing up ahead, sight to see even for a woman who’s seen her share of har places. EXT. BARRIO — DAY Jaime standing beside his cab, looking on as Sharon approaches what can only be described as poor, wretched, squalor. From the look on his face, he does not want to allow her make this walk alone and yet, Sharon continues on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon reaching the third level of this makeshift walk-up rounds a banister and finds herself in a dim corridor, apartment doors on either side running back toward the sunlight. She begins down the hall, the doors of all these places a to various degrees, Sharon peeking into each cautiously. At the end of the hall, Sharon easing toward a cracked do With care, she places her foot within the threshold, nudg the door wide as the space of her shoulders. SHARON'S VIEW: within the room, a thin, blonde-haired gir going about cleaning. Sharon is staring. The girl is pregnant. VICTORIA turns, feels Sharon watching. A brief beat of th facing one another, ten, twelve feet between them. From h indifferent look, Victoria has no idea who Sharon is.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rogers? Victoria's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No, Sefiora. You are mistaken. I am Sanchez.  88. They watch each other. Sharon is still leaning in the ent Victoria makes a movement toward the door, as though to c it, but stops. She touches the crucifix at her throat.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Senora, but I have work to do, if you please? I don't know any Mrs. Rogers. Maybe in one of the other places around here? She looks at Sharon with bitterness. Sharon straightens a for the first time, they are looking each other in the ey

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I have a photograph of you. Sharon takes out the photograph of Victoria and holds it Victoria walks toward the door. As she advances, Sharon m from the threshold, meets her in the room.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Sefiora, I have my work to do. What do you want with me? I do not know you.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I know you don't know me. Maybe you never even heard of me. Victoria shifting, something resigned in her stance. A de sigh, a dig into her pocket, reveals a pack of cigarettes

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Do you smoke, Sefora? She extends the pack toward Sharon. There is a plea in Victoria's eyes and Sharon, with a sha hand, takes the cigarette and Victoria lights it for her. puts the pack back into the pocket of her housecoat.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I know you don't know me. But you must have heard of me. Victoria looks briefly at the photograph of herself in Sharon's hand; looks at Sharon.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Look. I ain't got nothing against nobody. But I got to ask you to get out of here.  89.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I'm here to try to get a man out of prison. That man is going to marry my daughter. And he did not rape you. Sharon takes out the photograph of Tish and Fonny.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Look at this. Victoria turns away, sits on the unmade bed. Sharon approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Look at it, please. This is my daughter. The man with her is Alonzo Hunt. Is this the man who raped you? Victoria will not look at the photograph, or at Sharon.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Is this the man who raped you? Victoria looks down at the photograph, briefly, then up a Sharon.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It looks like him. (and, coldly) But he wasn't laughing when he was raping me. That taking the air out of Sharon, her breath going shall at its utterance, can feel Victoria calcifying in the mom

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: May I sit down? Victoria says nothing. Sharon sits beside her, on the bed After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Look, lady, before you go any further, just let me tell you, you can't do nothing to me, I ain't alone here, I got people.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to do anything to you. I'm just trying to get a man out of jail. An innocent man.  90.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Lady, I think you in the wrong place. Ain't no reason to talk to me. Ain't nothing I can do. Sharon looks away from her, out the window, the scramble her thoughts wrought clear on her face.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (cautious) How long were you in New York?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Too long.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Did you leave your children there?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Listen. Leave my children out of this. It’s hot, Sharon takes off her jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Why did you come back here? Victoria rises and walks to the window. Sharon follows, t two of them staring out at the sea together. A prolonged silence, a fleeting truce inspired by this view.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Daughter... in this world, terrible things happen to you, and we can all do some terrible things. Sharon is careful; she’s close, watching Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I was a woman before you was a woman — remember that. And I know, I know, you pay for the lies you tell. She stares at Victoria. Victoria stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You've put a man in jail, a man you've never seen. He's twenty-two years old, he wants to marry my daughter. She releases Victoria’s gaze, turns back to the window.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I did see him.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You saw him in the police lineup. That's the first time you saw him, the only time.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Because I've known him all his life. Victoria looking back to Sharon, huffing with a scorn tha runs deep, runs certain and heavy.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: One thing I can tell, lady: you ain't never been raped. That statement registering viscerally: Victoria has been raped. By someone.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You might have known a nice little boy, and he might be a nice man — with you! But you don't know the man who did — who did — what he did to me.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: But are you... are you sure that you know him?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure! They took me down there and they asked me to pick him out and that’s what I did, I picked him out.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: But you were... it happened in the dark. You saw Alonzo in the lights.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: There's lights in the hallway, I saw enough. Sharon grabs her again, and touches the crucifix.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Daughter... in the name of God.  92. Victoria looks down at Sharon’s hand on the cross... and screams: a piercing, impossible sound. She breaks away fr Sharon, runs to the door (which has remained open all thi time).

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Get out of here! Get out! Victoria is screaming in Spanish. Doors open. People begi appear. Sharon hears the horn of Jaime’s taxi. One of the older women in the hall comes to the door, and takes Victoria in her arms. Victoria collapses, weeping, this woman's breasts; and the woman, without a look at Sharon, leads her away into the hall. Everyone else is staring at Sharon. An interminable silen Off the sound of Jaime's horn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is it day? Hard to tell, the light, the sound, the ton everything here suspended in that in-between place, neith night nor day, present nor past. Fonny is working on the wood. It is a soft, brown wood, i stands on his worktable. The wall is covered with sketche His tools are on the table. He walks around the wood, terrified. He does not want to touch it. He knows that he must. But he does not want to defile the wood. He stares and stares, almost weeping. He is waiting for t wood to speak. Until it speaks, he cannot move. He picks up a chisel, he puts it down. He lights a cigare sits down on his work stool, stares, picks up the chisel again. He puts it down, goes into the kitchen to pour himself a beer. Comes back with the beer, sits down on the stool again, stares at the wood. The wood stares back.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You cunt. He picks up the chisel again, and approaches the waiting wood. Touches it very lightly with his hand, caresses it. listens.  93. He puts the chisel, teasingly, against it. The chisel beg to move. Fonny begins, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fonny lying here, eyes wide, staring at the ceiling. A beat of him lying this way, unblinking, looking far off away to that vision, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish at the glass, waiting as Fonny approaches from the o side. Seeing him in the light now, he looks different than we'v seen him previously, decidedly worse: gaunt, thinned. Fonny looks to Tish, looks into her as he takes up the ph

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: The baby all right?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. The baby's fine. He grins. It is, somehow, a shock to Tish.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: We got to get some meat on your bones, Lord, have mercy.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Speak up. He can't hear you. That playful, said with a smile, the best of Fonny.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (hesitant) But listen... there’s something I gotta tell you. Fonny nodding, readying himself:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Mama came back from Puerto Rico. She found Victoria, but...  94.

dialogues.speaker: TISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the girl went crazy, they don’t know where she is now. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: So the trial might get postponed. Fonny holding Tish’s gaze here, knows she’s watching him, does everything in his power to keep it together, to not break, the strain on that receiver in his hand palpable.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Fonny...

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. A deliberate beat as Fonny changes before her, something seeming to drift away from him, drain from his face.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Hayward’s not charging us no more, we almost got the money to bail you out. Takes a moment, just enough for the delay to read:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I figured you would. Every word out of Fonny’s mouth here bittersweet.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Listen, I'll be out soon. Tish’s face, at once shocked and yet trying hard to mask

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: I'm coming home because I'm glad I came, can you dig that? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: See now? I'm an artisan. Like a cat who makes tables. I don't like the word artist. Maybe I never did. I sure the fuck don't know what it means. I'm a cat who works from his gut, with his hands. I know what it's about now. I think I really do. Even if I go under. But I don't think I will now. I know I won’t.  95. He’s far from her. Here with her, yes. But very far away.

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Baby, I love you. And I'm going to build us a table and a whole lot of folks going to be eating off it for a long, long time to come. (and) And I'm all right, too. Don't you worry. I'm coming home. I'm coming home, to you. I want you in my arms. I want your arms around me. I've got to hold our baby in my arms. It's got to be. You keep the faith. Fonny grinning now, something bringing him back:

dialogues.speaker: FONNY
dialogues.text: Don't you worry. I'll be home. Fonny grins again, stands and extends his fist to the gla as always. A moment of those fists there, as though transferring the warmth through that barrier, then... ...-Fonny bends to kiss the glass. CUT TO BLACK. “I saw Bell everywhere... and all the time. We spoke once."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very pregnant Tish rising from the subway station, a pa sack clutched in her arms, gang of knickknacks spilling o the lip of it. She's a bit frantic, in a hurry as she hits the sidewalk looks up to double-check where she is, get her bearings. A half a block with her this way, this hurried gate, then .».-she hits the corner, red-light at the crosswalk. The streets full with the mid-afternoon rush. Tish taking all in, glad for a brief respite here at the corner when. ..-she looks left, sees a familiar face: Officer Bell. Approaching up the avenue, taking his time, not a hint of hurry to him, the spitting image of “whistling Dixie.”  96. Tish glancing to the light, sees it go yellow, but... rat than cross, she turns toward the avenue, turns to face Be meet him head on as he nears. That smile of his. That ridiculous fucking smile.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: Can I carry that for you?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: No. (and) No thank you. Tish looks into his eyes. There is something passing betw them, deliberate and fierce. Bell watching and Tish not looking away, nor betraying herself: gives him no emotion, just the veil.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: Well, you ain't got far to go. Sure wish I could carry it for you, though. Bell steps closer now, close enough that Tish looks about herself, looks as though to see if anybody’s watching:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: I ain't a bad guy. You ain't got to be afraid of me.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. Beat. An extended, unbearable beat.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BELL
dialogues.text: Good-night, then, miss lady.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Good-night, Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only time we’ve been here not focused on that side ta so synonymous with Tish and Fonny. Instead, find Tish huddled to herself in a table near the back, away from anyone else. Tish staring at the plate before her, a simple paella. Fr the looks of it, she hasn’t touched it. As he passes, Pedrocito deftly takes the plate without stopping.  97. A beat with Tish, the simple loneliness on her face, then ..-Pedrocito returning, appearing from the direction he'd escaped to, has a fresh plate in hand. Sits it before her, the heat of it releasing waves of vap into the air.

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: Sefiorita? Por favor. He and the muchacho need your strength. He will not forgive us if we let you starve. We are his friends. He trusts us. You must trust us, too. He takes a glass, pours her a little red wine.

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: Wine is good. Just a little. Slowly. Tish nods, takes a sip of the wine.

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: It will be a boy. Pedrocito grins; in some way a grin that recalls Fonny, t first night of Tish seeing the joy the men shared. Tish looking after him as he moves away, attends to the f customers here. A beat of her processing this moment, a suggestion of the warmth of the gesture coming over her, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish in the backseat but, not a cab, up in the front: Pedrocito. He won’t let her walk, he’s driving her home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish startles in the back seat, Pedrocito’s eyes going to rearview:

dialogues.speaker: PEDROCITO
dialogues.text: I told you, it’s a boy! Tish smiling as she re-settles herself: this man is famil A beat more of travel then... the car easing to a red lig nothing out of the ordinary, just a red light.  98. Tish lolling her head against the window, lets the light her face. Eyes wander away now, on the curb they’re idlin near. At a subdued, but distinct startle in her expressio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-Ernestine and her young actress there, the two of them close, the two of them more than close: the unmistakable of intimacy as they cradle one another on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TISH
dialogues.text: The car pulling away, Tish slumped down in that back seat though hiding, pure instinct, her eyes straining to catch last few glimpses of Ernestine and her lover. Tish sitting upright as Pedrocito drives on. Hold on her face, the fright of a child who’s seen what s should not see. And that quickly giving way to awe and, ultimately, a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish sitting in her chair, looking up out the small windo the sun faint, nearly night out. That bag she was carrying sitting on the table beside her She reaches for it and... lurches fully, doubles over lik something strong and full of purpose just socked her. The moment passing, Tish checking her watch and looking a the door again. A resigned sigh and she stands, looks dow into that bag and begins pulling things from it. A few small items at first and then, surprisingly, a bloc wood. Takes the wood, walks it over to Fonny’s work table goes to set the block there as... the phone rings. Tish’s hand at her belly as she moves to the phone. Gets hand on the receiver but takes a breath before picking it does so only after her breathing calms.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Hello, Tish? This is Adrienne. Tish’s face: Adrienne? Has she ever called here?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: How are you, Adrienne?  99.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you seen my father? Is he there? When did you see him last?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Why? I haven't seen him, I know he's seen Joseph, but I haven't-- The weeping through the phone startling Tish:

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Adrienne? Adrienne talk to me, what's the matter? Sound of Adrienne getting herself together on the other e stifling those sobs: Adrienne, don't--

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My Daddy was fired from his job two days ago, they said he was stealing, and they threatened to put him in jail and with Fonny and all he was just so... I don’t know. And he was drunk when he came home and he cursed everybody out and then he went out the door and ain't nobody seen him since; Tish, don't you know where my father is?

dialogues.speaker: TISH ADRIENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I swear to God, I Tish, I know you don't like me-—

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Adrienne, you and me, we had a little fight, but that don't mean I don't like you. You're Fonny's sister. And if I love him, I got to love you. And that don’t matter ‘cause I don’t wish for nothin’ bad on nobody.

dialogues.speaker: ADRIENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you see him, will you call me?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes, of course I will, Adrienne. Of course. Tish slowly removing the phone from her ear, shock runnin through her face when...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?  100. Tish looking to that voice, sees Sharon closing the apart door behind her, removing her key from the dead-bolt.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You look like you seen a ghost. Tish hanging up that phone finally, leans her weight on t table there. After she does, not a kick, but... something

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tish, what's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: (sitting) That was Adrienne. She's looking for Frank. She said he, he got fired and he was real upset. And Adrienne, that poor child sounds like she's gone to pieces. Mama, has Daddy seen him? Sharon's still; still standing, still watching. She’s listening, yes, but also studying, evaluating.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I don't know. But he ain't been by, no. Sharon setting her bag down, crosses the room and puts a to Tish’s brow:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Tired. Funny.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You want me to get you a little brandy?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you, Mama. That might be a good idea. It might help to settle my stomach. Sharon heads into the kitchen, knows just where Tish keep the Brandy, rather than pour it brings the bottle and a s glass over, sits them beside Tish. Sharon nodding at questions in her own head, studying Tis  101.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Your stomach upset?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: A little. It'll go away. Sharon watching as Tish opens the bottle, takes a small s from it, doesn’t bother with the glass. Sharon moving to kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You see Fonny today?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: And how was he?

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: He's beautiful. They beat him up, but they didn't beat him, you know?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I know baby, I know. Sharon returning with a damp towel, rubs at Tish’s temple

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I think Ernestine's got the rest of the money. From her actress. A flash across Tish’s face, mind alight. Doesn’t say anything, wasn’t about to say anything but... the doorbel rings, Sharon setting that towel down and moving over to it. Opens it and, her back to Tish, obscuring whoever’s t but... her voice, pure terror:

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: What happen? Tish standing, looking on as Sharon turns back inside, reveals Joseph coming in behind her, a heavy look about h

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: It’s Frank. (and) They found Frank.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: Does Fonny know?  102.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Not yet. He won't know till morning.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I've got to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You can't get there till morning, daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I’ve got to tell him now--

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tish, you can’t--

dialogues.speaker: TISH
dialogues.text: I've got to.... Tish trailing off there, like she’s been dazed, losing th train of thought as it’s formed. She stares at the entry there, still open, the cement wall rising up to the sidew

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: How you feeling? The sky opening... or something similar to it — to the so of it — rising from Tish’s chest, hand to her belly. Joseph jolted, a step toward Tish and then a step back as Sharon reaches a hand to stop him, all calm. Sharon putting a hand to Tish’s shoulder, eases her the couple steps back to her chair, gently sits her there.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (without looking away) Call the ambulance, Joseph. And as her father moves to the phone, his presence long g from here, Tish looks to her mother, looks up to her, Sharon’s image as strong and loving and in spirit as ever

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Don’t panic, baby. Remember, love brought you here. Sharon smiles, and... CUT TO BLACK.
